Abstract: A method is suggested which allows truncation of the virtual space in Cholesky decomposition-based multiconfigurational perturbation theory (CD-CASPT2) calculations with systematic improvability of the results. The method is based on a modified version of the frozen natural orbital (FNO) approach used in coupled cluster theory. The idea is to exploit the near-linear dependence among the eigenvectors of the virtual-virtual block of the second-order Møller-Plesset density matrix. It is shown that FNO-CASPT2 recovers more than 95% of the full CD-CASPT2 correlation energy while requiring only a fraction of the total virtual space, especially when large atomic orbital basis sets are in use. Tests on various properties commonly investigated with CASPT2 demonstrate the reliability of the approach and the associated reduction in computational cost and storage demand of the calculations. © 2009 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Kissin M.L.G., Boys J.T., Covic G.A.
Title: Interphase mutual inductance in polyphase inductive power transfer systems
Affiliations: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, The University of Auckland, 1142 Auckland, New Zealand
Authors with affiliations: Kissin, M.L.G., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, The University of Auckland, 1142 Auckland, New Zealand; Boys, J.T., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, The University of Auckland, 1142 Auckland, New Zealand; Covic, G.A., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, The University of Auckland, 1142 Auckland, New Zealand
Abstract: Roadway powered electric vehicles with minimal or no onboard energy storage have been proposed for many years, but the concept has only recently become feasible via three-phase inductive power transfer (IPT) systems. A wide zone can be created over which power transfer is relatively constant. This gives good tolerance to the alignment of the pickup relative to the track allowing simple low-cost pickup structures to be used. While three-phase IPT tracks make the vehicle pickup and power transfer simpler, they are difficult for the power supply to drive due to the presence of mutual coupling between the track phases resulting from the physical layout of the track. These mutual inductances induce voltages within each track phase that, because of the inductor-capacitor-inductor network, cause large currents within the power supply inverter and imbalances within the system. This paper presents an analytical assessment of the problems caused by the interphase mutual inductance, and three possible solutions. Two of the methods involve modifications to the track layout to alter or remove the mutual inductances, while the third and preferred technique requires additional ferrite cores between the various phases to compensate this adverse mutual inductance without affecting the power transfer to the pickup loads. © 2009 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Electromagnetic induction; Mutual coupling

Title: Energy level alignment in CdS quantum dot sensitized solar cells using molecular dipoles
Source title: Journal of the American Chemical Society
Affiliations: Institute of Nanotechnology and Advanced Materials, Department of Chemistry, Bar Ilan University, 52900 Ramat Gan, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Shalom, M., Institute of Nanotechnology and Advanced Materials, Department of Chemistry, Bar Ilan University, 52900 Ramat Gan, Israel; Rühle, S., Institute of Nanotechnology and Advanced Materials, Department of Chemistry, Bar Ilan University, 52900 Ramat Gan, Israel; Hod, I., Institute of Nanotechnology and Advanced Materials, Department of Chemistry, Bar Ilan University, 52900 Ramat Gan, Israel; Yahav, S., Institute of Nanotechnology and Advanced Materials, Department of Chemistry, Bar Ilan University, 52900 Ramat Gan, Israel; Zaban, A., Institute of Nanotechnology and Advanced Materials, Department of Chemistry, Bar Ilan University, 52900 Ramat Gan, Israel
Abstract: (Figure Presented) The energy levels of CdS quantum dots (QDs) can be shifted in a systematic fashion with respect to the TiO2 bands using molecular dipoles. Dipole moments pointing toward the QD surface shift the energy levels toward the vacuum level (a), thus enabling electron injection from excited QD states into the TiO2 conduction band at lower photon energies compared to QDs with adsorbed molecular dipoles which are pointing away from the QD surface (b). In CdS QD sensitized solar cells this leads to a dipole dependent shift of the photovoltage onset and the photocurrent. © 2009 American Chemical Society.

Title: Gas market seeks sign
Authors with affiliations: Fletcher, S.
Abstract: The US gas industry is keenly studying the market conditions and other developments taking place in the market amidst reduced drilling. There was a 12% price increase for the front-month contract on the New York Mercantile Exchange in mid-July 2009 following four consecutive weeks of natural gas injections into the US storage, with the contract bringing up to $3.67/MMbtu on July 16. This followed after the Energy Information Administration reported the infusion of 90 bcf of gas into the US storage. Meanwhile, drilling permits rose 4.3% in June in 30 states. Baker Hughes Inc. reported 920 rotary rigs operating in the US in the week ended July 17. Meanwhile, crude futures prices increased above $62/bbl in mid-July following a report on economic growth in China.

Title: Techview smart-grid report maps opportunities for U.S. Engineers
Abstract: The Electric Power Research Institute (EPRI) released its report on the Smart Grid Interoperability Standards Roadmap to National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST). NIST had engaged EPRI and other Smart Grid stakeholders to develop a draft interim-standards roadmap that was to be used by it to begin developing standards. The report was comprised of a general overview of the efforts to define the Smart Grid, a conceptual model to think about it, and its implementation. Other issues discussed in the report included cyber security, wide-area situation awareness (WASA), market communications, and distributed generation and energy storage (DG). It was informed that the Smart Grid was to be characterized by a two-way flow of electricity and information to create an automated and widely distributed energy delivery network.

Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Abstract: The proceedings contain 9 papers. The topics discussed include: SPECrate2006: alternatives considered, lessons learned; SPECjvm2008 performance characterization; performance characterization of Itanium® 2-based montecito processor; a tale of two Processors: revisiting the RISC-CISC debate; investigating cache parameters of x86 family processors; the next frontier for power/performance benchmarking: energy efficiency of storage subsystems; thermal design space exploration of 3D die stacked multi-core processors using geospatial-based predictive models; Generation, validation and analysis of SPEC CPU2006 simulation points based on branch, memory and TLB characteristics; and a note on the effects of service time distribution in the M/G/1 queue.

Title: Two-level dictionary code compression: A new scheme to improve instruction code density of embedded applications
Source title: Proceedings of the 2009 CGO - 7th International Symposium on Code Generation and Optimization
Affiliations: KTH School of Information and Communication Technology, Royal Institute of Technology, Stockholm, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Collin, M., KTH School of Information and Communication Technology, Royal Institute of Technology, Stockholm, Sweden; Brorsson, M., KTH School of Information and Communication Technology, Royal Institute of Technology, Stockholm, Sweden
Abstract: Dictionary code compression is a technique which has been studied as a method to reduce the energy consumed in the instruction fetch path of processors. Instructions or instruction sequences in the code are replaced with short code words. These code words are later used to index a dictionary which contains the original uncompressed instruction or an entire sequence. In this paper, we present a new method which improves on code density compared to previously published dictionary methods. It uses a two-level dictionary design and is capable of handling compression of both individual instructions and code sequences of 2-16 instructions. The two dictionaries are in separate pipeline stages and work together to decompress sequences and instructions. The impact on storage size for the dictionaries is rather small as the sequences in the dictionary are stored as individually compressed instructions, instead of normal instructions. Compared to previous dictionary code compression methods we achieve improved dynamic compression rate, potential for better performance with reasonable static compression rate and with still small dictionary size suitable for context switching. © 2009 IEEE.

Abstract: A brackish water Reverse Osmosis (BWRO) desalination unit is studied in this paper. This unit is designed to be fed by a renewable energy based on hybrid source (wind and photovoltaic: hybrid system) with/without storage battery. The energy will be directly transmitted to the motos-pump of the BWRO process. An appropriate energy management starts from the understanding of the BWRO desalination process with its energy consumption. To optimize the energy transfer towards the load, it is useful to study the mechanical and the hydraulic system behaviour. Experimental characterizations of the motos-pumps and hydraulic load are elaborated from which significant results are drawn. ©2009 IEEE.

In this paper, the authors investigated a FESS associated to PMSM-wind turbine connected to the grid via a three-phase PWM inverter. The FESS is controlled by a FOC (Flux Oriented Control) strategy cascaded with an external power loop for the supervision of the power reference value. Abstract: Due to the superparamagnetism, the configuration of magnetic recording system has to be changed in order to enhance the writing capability or to reduce the number of grains per bit. The next target of magnetic recording research is to enable IIDD technologies at the areal density of 10 Th/in2. This work studies the feasibility and the requirement to implement the magnetic recording system at 10 Tb/in2. From the analysis of two possible approaches: the energy assisted magnetic recording (EAMR) on granular media and the bit patterned media (BPM) with EAMR, the simulation based virtual design of magnetic recording system at 10 Tb/in2 is proposed.

Abstract: Servo and mechanical approaches are presented in this paper with a view to minimize repeatable runout (RRO) component of track-following position error signal (PES) in high TPI (Track Per Inch) hard disk drives. The harmonics of the RRO are identified and catalogized in the context of real-time RRO and written-in RRO harmonics. Combination of empirical PES measurements, review of relative analytical works, and working servo and mechanical design solution methods will be systematically discussed through this paper.

Abstract: This paper proposes a filtering method to filter out impulses in the position error signal (PES) due to corrupt servo pattern or demodulation timing in hard disk drives. The impulse disturbance, leading to a sudden change in PES, may be distributed separately or consecutively. A nonlinear switched filtering method is used to smooth the PES before feeding into servo controller. With the nonlinear switched filter, the PES is significantly reduced without degrading the stability and bandwidth of the servo loop under certain conditions.
Author Keywords: Hard disk drives; Impulse disturbance; Nonlinear filtering; Position error signal

Abstract: We present a computational screening study of ternary metal borohydrides for reversible hydrogen storage based on density functional theory. We investigate the stability and decomposition of alloys containing 1 alkali metal atom, Li, Na, or K (M1); and 1 alkali, alkaline earth or 3d/4d transition metal atom (M2) plus two to five (BH4) - groups, i.e., M1 M2 (BH4) 2-5, using a number of model structures with trigonal, tetrahedral, octahedral, and free coordination of the metal borohydride complexes. Of the over 700 investigated structures, about 20 were predicted to form potentially stable alloys with promising decomposition energies. The M1 (Al/Mn/Fe) (BH4) 4, (Li/Na) Zn (BH4)3, and (Na/K) (Ni/Co) (BH4) 3 alloys are found to be the most promising, followed by selected M1 (Nb/Rh) (BH4) 4 alloys. © 2009 American Institute of Physics.

Title: Blue nano titania made in diffusion flames
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical and Process Engineering, Particle Technology Laboratory, Institute of Process Engineering, Sonneggstrasse 3, 8092 Zurich, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Teleki, A., Department of Mechanical and Process Engineering, Particle Technology Laboratory, Institute of Process Engineering, Sonneggstrasse 3, 8092 Zurich, Switzerland; Pratsinis, S.E., Department of Mechanical and Process Engineering, Particle Technology Laboratory, Institute of Process Engineering, Sonneggstrasse 3, 8092 Zurich, Switzerland
Abstract: Blue titanium suboxide nanoparticles (including Magneli phases) were formed directly without any post-processing or addition of dopants by combustion of titanium-tetra-isopropoxide (TTIP) vapor at atmospheric pressure. Particle size, phase composition, rutile and anatase crystal sizes as well as the blue coloration were controlled by rapid quenching of the flame with a critical flow nozzle placed at various heights above the burner. The particles showed a broad absorption in the near-infrared region and retained their blue color upon storage in ambient atmosphere. A high concentration of paramagnetic Ti 3+ centres was found in the substoichiometric particles by electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectroscopy. Furthermore particles with controlled band gap energy from 3.2 to 3.6 eV were made by controlling the burner-nozzle-distance from 10 to 1 cm, respectively. The color robustness and extent of suboxidation could be further enhanced by co-oxidation of TTIP with hexamethyldisiloxane in the flame resulting in SiO2-coated titanium suboxide particles. The process is cost-effective and green while the particles produced can replace traditional blue colored, cobalt-containing pigments. © 2009 the Owner Societies.

Authors: Meza-Jiménez J., Ramírez-Ruiz J., Luna-Solano G., Andrade-González I.
Title: Low-cost solar thermodynamic drying system for the dehydration of roselle (Hibiscus sabdarifa L.)
Affiliations: Industrial Engineering Department, Instituto Tecnológico de Colima, de Alvarez, Colima, Mexico; Engineering and Manufacturing Intitute, Universidad Autónoma de Cd. Juarez, Chihuahua, Mexico; DEP, Instituto Tecnológico de Orizaba, Orizaba, Veracruz, Mexico; Instituto Tecnológico Agropecuario de Jalisco, Tlajomulco de Zúñiga, Jal, Mexico
Authors with affiliations: Meza-Jiménez, J., Industrial Engineering Department, Instituto Tecnológico de Colima, de Alvarez, Colima, Mexico; Ramírez-Ruiz, J., Engineering and Manufacturing Intitute, Universidad Autónoma de Cd. Juarez, Chihuahua, Mexico; Luna-Solano, G., DEP, Instituto Tecnológico de Orizaba, Orizaba, Veracruz, Mexico; Andrade-González, I., Instituto Tecnológico Agropecuario de Jalisco, Tlajomulco de Zúñiga, Jal, Mexico
Abstract: The novel low-cost band thermodynamic dryer equipped with a solar collector, a parabolic focusing collector, a heat exchanger, screw fan, and a drying cabinet with a band was designed and tested. The maximum temperature in the solar collector reached 85°C, which was 55°C above the ambient temperature. The required drying time was 4.5 h, much reduced from the traditional solar drying time of 48 h. The final moisture content of the Roselle calyx was 12% w.b., which is the recommended storage moisture content. Measurements of ambient temperature and humidity, air temperature, and relative humidity inside the dryer as well as solids moisture loss-in-weight data are employed as a means to study the performance of the dryer. Solar drying was compared with conventional sun drying and heated air drying, using the following evaluation criteria: drying time, dried Roselle color, texture, taste, and production cost. For evaluation, a model-based Technique for Order Preference by Similarity to Ideal Solution (TOPSIS) methodology was used. After the evaluation, the proposed continuous solar dryer was found to be better than conventional drying and heated air drying due to slower drying rate and better quality of the dried Roselle.
Author Keywords: Low cost; Parabolic collector; Roselle calyx; Solar dryer; Thermodynamics system
Index Keywords: Air temperature; Ambient temperatures; Conventional drying; Drying rates; Drying systems; Drying time; Evaluation criteria; Final moisture content; Heated air; Low cost; Maximum temperature; Model-based; Moisture contents; Moisture loss; Parabolic collector; Production cost; Relative humidities; Roselle calyx; Solar drying; Sun drying; Technique for order preference by similarity to ideal solutions; Atmospheric humidity; Costs; Dewatering; Drying; Hemp; Hot air heating; Moisture; Moisture determination; Solar collectors; Solar dryers; Solar energy; Solar heating; Temperature; Thermodynamics; Curing

Authors: Van Dijk M., Van Vuuren S.J.
Title: Destratifcation induced by bubble plumes as a means to reduce evaporation from open impoundments
Affiliations: Department of Civil Engineering, University of Pretoria, Pretoria 0001, South Africa
Authors with affiliations: Van Dijk, M., Department of Civil Engineering, University of Pretoria, Pretoria 0001, South Africa; Van Vuuren, S.J., Department of Civil Engineering, University of Pretoria, Pretoria 0001, South Africa
Abstract: The use of thermal mixing by means of compressed air appears to have important potential for evaporation suppression on deep reservoirs. Current methods used to reduce evaporation from open-water impoundments such as foating covers, modular covers, monolayers and shade structures have many disadvantages and negative impacts on the environment. These methods impact the natural/modifed aquatic ecosystem established in the dam; alter aesthetic qualities; increase the risk of dam failure in times of food; could potentially lead to an oxygen reduction in the water; and may compromise the natural water treatment functions and operations such as the reduction of harmful bacteria, exposure to sunlight (form of disinfection) and natural and mechanical aeration thereby increasing treatment costs. The methodology proposed in this paper to help reduce evaporation losses from open-water impoundments, which indirectly addresses problems of water shortage and the associated economic impacts, involves the destratifcation of the water body using a bubble plume operated with minimal energy input to reduce surface water temperatures, with, a subsequent reduction in evaporation. The literature, although limited, indicates that this proposed method has merit and requires further research to identify specifc reservoirs (size, depth, usage) that could beneft from such a destratifcation system. Evaporation suppression of as high as 30 % was achieved in some case studies.
Author Keywords: Bubble plume; Destratifcation; Evaporation reduction; Evaporation suppression

Title: Measurements and calculations of hydrocarbon mixtures liquid density by simple cubic equations of state
Affiliations: Thermodynamic Research Laboratory, Kashan University, Kashan, Iran
Authors with affiliations: Mohsen-Nia, M., Thermodynamic Research Laboratory, Kashan University, Kashan, Iran; Rasa, H., Thermodynamic Research Laboratory, Kashan University, Kashan, Iran
Abstract: The continuing importance of pressure-volume-temperature (PVT) property calculations of reservoir fluids mixtures in design of equipments used for storage, transportation and separation processes need considerable experimental and theoretical attempts to present a simple, accurate and theoretical based equation of state to replace the existing empirical based equations of state. The first author and his co-workers previously presented two parameters cubic theoretical based equation of state (MMM). This equation was used in PVT and vapour-liquid-equilibrium (VLE) calculations of pure and fluid mixtures. The comparisons for the different pure and mixture fluids calculations indicated the advantages of this equation of state over the well-known empirical-based two parameters cubic equation of state (RK EOS). In this study, PVT data for binary, ternary, quaternary and multicomponent oil mixtures at the different temperature and ambient pressure are measured, and reported. The measured PVT data were compared with those obtained by using the simple cubic equations of state. The calculated results by MMM EOS are compared with SRK and PR EOSs which are the commonly used three parameters cubic EOSs in the oil and gas calculations. The comparisons indicate that, although the SRK and PR EOSs needs an additional parameter (acentric factor, ω), the MMM equation of state is more accurate than both SRK and PR equations for the PVT calculations of oil mixtures.

Authors: Committee on Review of the Research Program of the FreedomCAR and Fuel Partnership, Phase 3, National Research Council, Board on Energy and Environmental Systems, Division on Engineering and Physical Sciences
Title: Letter report on the review of the research program of the FreedomCAR and Fuel Partnership, phase 3
Source title: Letter Report on the Review of the Research Program of the FreedomCAR and Fuel Partnership, Phase 3
Authors with affiliations: Committee on Review of the Research Program of the FreedomCAR and Fuel Partnership, Phase 3; National Research Council; Board on Energy and Environmental Systems; Division on Engineering and Physical Sciences
Abstract: This letter report broadly reviews the strategy and structure of the FreedomCAR and Fuel Partnership, as requested by the U.S. Department of Energy. Although the Obama Administration's focus on nearer-term technologies is on the right track, there remains a need for continued investment in longer-term, higher-risk, higher-payoff vehicle technologies that could be highly transformational with regard to reduced use of petroleum and reduced emissions. Such technologies include advanced batteries, technologies for hydrogen storage, and hydrogen/fuel cells. For researchers, contractors, and investors to be willing to make long-term commitments to these and other potentially important developing technologies, a consistent year-to-year level of support must be provided. Other recommendations within this report include incorporating a broader-scope approach to better consider total emissions and the full environmental impact of using various fuels and technologies; providing temporary reductions in cost-share requirements to ease the burden on prospective researchers; and providing direct funding to struggling automotive companies to help keep important in-house research programs active. Further suggestions are included within the body of the report. © 2009 by the National Academy of Sciences. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Environmental impact; Fuels; Hydrogen storage; Investments; Automotive companies; Cost shares; Freedomcar; Research programs; Total emissions; U.S. Department of Energy; Vehicle technology; Environmental technology

Title: IEEE Electric Ship Technologies Symposium, ESTS 2009
Source title: IEEE Electric Ship Technologies Symposium, ESTS 2009
Abstract: The proceedings contain 83 papers. The topics discussed include: feasibility study of noise pattern analysis based ground fault locating method for ungrounded DC shipboard power distribution systems; statistically robust design for the all-electric ship from a network theoretic perspective; a modern and open real-time digital simulator of all-electric ships with a multi-platform co-simulation approach; investigation of accelerating numerical-field analysis methods for electric machines with the Incorporation of graphic-processor based parallel processing techniques; analytical model-based analysis of high-speed flywheel energy storage systems for pulsed power applications; estimating transient response of simple AC and DC shipboard power systems to pulse load operations; and cognitive engineering studies of DSS and dealing with uncertainty in load for real-time adaptive power system reconfiguration.

Title: Surface Plasmon-Enhanced Photoemission and Electron Acceleration with Ultrashort Laser Pulses
Source title: Advances in Imaging and Electron Physics
Affiliations: Research Institute for Solid-State Physics and Optics, Konkoly-Thege M. út, Budapest, Hungary
Authors with affiliations: Dombi, P., Research Institute for Solid-State Physics and Optics, Konkoly-Thege M. út, Budapest, Hungary
Abstract: Surface plasmon-enhanced electron acceleration proved to be a powerful tool for the all-optical generation of ultrashort, high-repetition-rate electron beams with multi-kiloelectronvolt-range energy. More recent developments in the field include the investigation of this process with ultrashort laser pulses with a duration comparable to the surface plasmon lifetime and with pulses with high intensities so that field emission from the surface takes place. These developments are reviewed in this chapter together with earlier results on surface plasmon-enhanced photoemission and electron acceleration. Particular attention is paid to those photoemission and ultrafast photoacceleration mechanisms that sensitively shape the electron beam and determine its spectral, spatial, and temporal characteristics. A simple numerical treatment is also presented in detail that can be applied in a broad-parameter range to predict beam parameters. © 2009 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Electron acceleration; Surface plasmons; Ultrafast phenomena

Title: Eagle Crest Energy Company; Notice of application tendered for filing with the commission and soliciting additional study request
Abstract: On 6/23/2009, Eagle Crest energy Co filed an application for a major license for its Eagle Mountain Pumped Storage Project located in two depleted mining pits in the Eagle Mountain Mine in Riverside County, CA, near the Town of Desert Center, CA, and would occupy Federal lands administered by the US Bureau of Land Management and private lands owned by Kaiser Eagle Mountain LLC. The project would consist of a 191-acre upper reservoir impounded by two diversion dams with a total storage capacity of 20,000 acre-ft; a 163-acre lower reservoir with a total storage capacity of 21,900 acre-ft; a 29-ft-dia by 4000-ft-long low pressure upper tunnel; a surge tank with a 33-ft-diameter by 1348-ft-long tunnel shaft; a 29-ft-dia by 1560-ft-long high pressure lower tunnel; a 33-ft-dia by 6835-ft-long tailrace tunnel; a 72-ft wide, 130-ft-high, and 360-ft-long underground powerhouse; four reversible pump-turbine units at 325 Mw each, for a total installed capacity of 1300 Mw; a 28-ft-wide, 28-ft-high, by 6625-ftlong access tunnel to the underground powerhouse; a water supply pipeline ranging from 12- to 24-in. dia totaling 15.3 mi; a 13.5-mi-long, 500-kv transmission line connecting to a new Interconnection Collector Substation; and appurtenant facilities. The average annual generation is estimated to be 22.2 Gw-hr. The deadline for filing additional study requests and requests for cooperating agency status is on 8/21/2009.

Authors: Abu Rumman M., Hiyassat M., Alsmadi B., Jamrah A., Alqam M.
Title: A surface water management model for the Integrated Southern Ghor Project, Jordan
Affiliations: Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, University of Jordan, Amman, Jordan; Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, Hashemite University, Zarqa, Jordan
Authors with affiliations: Abu Rumman, M., Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, University of Jordan, Amman, Jordan; Hiyassat, M., Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, Hashemite University, Zarqa, Jordan; Alsmadi, B., Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, University of Jordan, Amman, Jordan; Jamrah, A., Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, University of Jordan, Amman, Jordan; Alqam, M., Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, University of Jordan, Amman, Jordan
Abstract: Purpose – The purpose of this paper is to assess the long-term ability of the Integrated Southern Ghor Project (ISGP) to meet the required water demands, assess the resulting energy requirements, pumping costs, water transfers, benefits of the current system with respect to predevelopment conditions and effect of projected water demands increase on the resulting water deficits. Design/methodology/approach – A surface water resources management model is developed using dynamic programming. The model inputs are the hydrological inflows from the different wadis in the project area, reservoirs characteristics and evaporation rates, system water demands. The model outputs are water deficits at the different demand areas, reservoirs storage and release sequences, water transfers and energy requirements and the associated costs. The average annual values of different performance criteria with the annual frequency curves are used to evaluate the implications of different water scenarios on the ISGP. Findings – The results show the efficiency of the ISGP model in reducing the water deficits in the demand areas as compared to predevelopment conditions. Increased demand scenario showed the importance of finding new water projects to supplement the Southern Ghor Area in the future in order to meet the increasing water demands. The proposed water transfer will reduce the resulting deficits at the agricultural areas without the expenses of increasing the water deficits at other demand areas. The application of this model is expected to enhance decision making regarding water policies in Jordan. Originality/value – This paper provides critical quantitative information to decision makers in Jordan about the potential of the different storage facilities and proposed transfers in meeting the required water demands in the Southern Ghor Project and assesses the required energy for that. This can help decision makers to have a holistic view about the expected water deficits in the area and therefore assist them in determining the areas impacted most and what alternative solution to use. The paper also shows the importance of using optimal control/management models to support water resources decision making in Jordan. © 2009, Emerald Group Publishing Limited
Author Keywords: Dams; Decision support systems; Jordan; Modelling; Reservoirs; Water retention and flow works

Title: Cluster head selection for homogeneous wireless sensor networks
Source title: International Conference on Advanced Communication Technology, ICACT
Affiliations: Advisor of General Director, Central Science Research Telecommunication Institute, Moscow, Russian Federation; Telecommunications University, Saint-Petersburg, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Koucheryavy, A., Advisor of General Director, Central Science Research Telecommunication Institute, Moscow, Russian Federation; Salim, A., Telecommunications University, Saint-Petersburg, Russian Federation
Abstract: Wireless Sensor Network (WSN) is an active area of research today. A WSN consists of a number of sensor nods each with limited energy, bandwidth, storage, and processing capability. Clustering is one of the basic approaches for designing energy-efficient, robust and highly scalable distributed sensor networks. One of the approaches to enhance the lifetime of WSN is to allow only some nodes in a cluster of sensor nodes, called cluster heads, to communicate with the base station. In this paper, we take a unique look at the cluster head election problem, specifically concentrating on Homogeneous Wireless Sensor Networks. Our approach for cluster-based network organization is based on a Voronoi diagram that favor nodes deployed in densely populated network areas as better candidates for cluster head nodes, active sensor nodes and routers.
Index Keywords: Active area; Active sensor; Cluster head; Cluster-based networks; Cluster-head nodes; Distributed sensor networks; Energy efficient; Network area; Processing capability; Voronoi diagrams; Energy efficiency; Routing protocols; Sensor networks; Sensor nodes; Telecommunication equipment; Wireless telecommunication systems; Wireless sensor networks

Authors: Zechner R., Kienesberger P.C., Haemmerle G., Zimmermann R., Lass A.
Title: Adipose triglyceride lipase and the lipolytic catabolism of cellular fat stores
Affiliations: Institute of Molecular Biosciences, University of Graz, Graz, Austria
Authors with affiliations: Zechner, R., Institute of Molecular Biosciences, University of Graz, Graz, Austria; Kienesberger, P.C., Institute of Molecular Biosciences, University of Graz, Graz, Austria; Haemmerle, G., Institute of Molecular Biosciences, University of Graz, Graz, Austria; Zimmermann, R., Institute of Molecular Biosciences, University of Graz, Graz, Austria; Lass, A., Institute of Molecular Biosciences, University of Graz, Graz, Austria
Abstract: Fatty acids (FAs) are essential components of all lipid classes and pivotal substrates for energy production in all vertebrates. Additionally, they act directly or indirectly as signaling molecules and, when bonded to amino acid side chains of peptides, anchor proteins in biological membranes. In vertebrates, FAs are predominantly stored in the form of triacylglycerol (TG) within lipid droplets of white adipose tissue. Lipid droplet-associated TGs are also found in most nonadipose tissues, including liver, cardiac muscle, and skeletal muscle. The mobilization of FAs from all fat depots depends on the activity of TG hydrolases. Currently, three enzymes are known to hydrolyze TG, the well-studied hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL) and monoglyceride lipase (MGL), discovered more than 40 years ago, as well as the relatively recently identified adipose triglyceride lipase (ATGL). The phenotype of HSL- and ATGL-deficient mice, as well as the disease pattern of patients with defective ATGL activity (due to mutation in ATGL or in the enzyme's activator, CGI-58), suggest that the consecutive action of ATGL, HSL, and MGL is responsible for the complete hydrolysis of a TG molecule. The complex regulation of these enzymes by numerous, partially uncharacterized effectors creates the "lipolysome," a complex metabolic network that contributes to the control of lipid and energy homeostasis. This review focuses on the structure, function, and regulation of lipolytic enzymes with a special emphasis on ATGL. Authors: Gordeev B.A., Maslov G.V., Bugaiskii V.V., Sinev A.V., Tumakov S.F., Gordeev A.B.
Title: Application of hydromounts in synchronizing mechanical systems testing
Source title: Journal of Machinery Manufacture and Reliability
Authors with affiliations: Gordeev, B.A.; Maslov, G.V.; Bugaiskii, V.V.; Sinev, A.V.; Tumakov, S.F.; Gordeev, A.B.
Abstract: This article considers the issues of the interaction of an excitation source - an asynchronous electric motor - in transient operation modes with external vibration fields that can be generated by foreign sources, in particular, by a vibrostand. It has been shown that in certain vibrostand operation modes, it is possible to observe the phenomenon of the electric motor rotor rotation frequency being captured by the external vibration field, resulting in a delay of the transient processes and extra consumption of the source energy. The results of experimental studies on the decrease in the vibration and noise levels with the use of asynchronous electric motors with hydromounts as dampers are presented. The economic prerequisites of hydromount application in power-consuming synchronizing mechanical systems have been substantiated. © Allerton Press, Inc. 2009.

Title: Notice of intent to prepare an environmental impact statement for the proposed Sonoran Solar Energy Project, Maricopa County, AZ
Abstract: The Bureau of Land Management plans to prepare an Environmental Impact Statement to address potential effects of a proposed solar energy project by Boulevard Associates LLC. This notice is announcing the beginning of the scoping process and soliciting input on the identification of issues. Boulevard Associates LLC would construct up to 375 Mw of solar thermal electrical generation with options for natural gas backup and/or thermal storage capabilities. The solar facility would consist of solar fields made up of single-axis-tracking parabolic trough solar collectors. To optimize the output capacity of the project, both natural gas backup and/or thermal energy storage would be used as needed. Natural gas backup would include the addition of a partial or full load burner arrangement that would generate additional steam when solar energy is absent or insufficient by itself. Annual output from natural gas would be limited to 25% of annual capacity to ensure that the plant remains predominantly a solar powered facility.

Authors: Cieslik J., Kula P., Filipek S.M.
Title: Research on compressor utilizing hydrogen storage materials for application in heat treatment facilities
Affiliations: Institute of Materials Science and Engineering, Technical University of Lodz, Stefanowskiego 1/15, 90-924 Lodz, Poland; Institute of Physical Chemistry, Polish Academy of Sciences, Kasprzaka 44/52, 01-224 Warsaw, Poland
Authors with affiliations: Cieslik, J., Institute of Materials Science and Engineering, Technical University of Lodz, Stefanowskiego 1/15, 90-924 Lodz, Poland; Kula, P., Institute of Materials Science and Engineering, Technical University of Lodz, Stefanowskiego 1/15, 90-924 Lodz, Poland; Filipek, S.M., Institute of Physical Chemistry, Polish Academy of Sciences, Kasprzaka 44/52, 01-224 Warsaw, Poland
Abstract: The design of hydrogen compressor utilizing hydrogen storage alloys for application in heat treatment facilities is presented. This compressor working between 0.02 and 3.3 MPa could be an alternative for a mechanical compressor. In laboratory experiments, a model of the hydride compressor was used (scale 1:13). The compressor model uses LaNi4.8Sn0.2 (45 kg) and LaNi4.25Al0.75 (3.5 kg) alloys closed in two separate containers equipped with heat exchangers. The alloys were being heated and cooled by oil flowing through the containers. It was noticed that penetration of hydrogen to the alloy bed situated in the lower part of the containers was not sufficient. The experiments have shown a high efficiency of heat exchangers mounted in the container with LaNi4.8Sn0.2 (finned tubes) and too small efficiency of heat exchangers mounted in the container with LaNi4.25Al0.75 (smooth tubes). The initial research of the stability of alloys subjected to many hydrogen absorption-desorption cycles (207 cycles) was carried out for 0.3-3.3 MPa pressure range (LaNi4.8Sn0.2 at 310-450 K) and 0.02-0.3 MPa (LaNi4.25Al0.75 at 315-410 K). The desorption isotherm for LaNi4.8Sn0.2 at 293 K was also determined. The experiments revealed that energy losses were too high to use the hydride compressor instead of a mechanical compressor in an industrial application. Reducing energy loss would be the most important point of further research. © 2009 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Gas quenching; Hydrogen recycling; Hydrogen storage materials

Title: Global financial collapse stalls growth in the petroleum sector
Authors with affiliations: Steakley, L.
Abstract: A collapse of the global financial crisis has driven down crude oil prices and consumer demand, causing oil producers to hit the pipeline, refinery, exploration and storage facility projects. Suncor Energy Inc. revised its spending budget and delayed plans to build a new upgrader at the company's Voyager oil-sands project north of Fort McMurray. The $20.6-billion expansion project would have increased crude-oil production at the facility by 200,000 barrels per day to 550,000 bpd. Leading U.S. refiner Valero Energy cut $800 million from its capital budget for 2009 by pushing back construction of a diesel hydrotreater and aromatics unit at its Norco refinery in Louisiana and the upgrade of a gasoline-making fluid catalytic cracking unit at its Memphis refinery. Jacobs, California, is continuing to work on the $3.8-billion modernization project of the BP Whiting Refinery in Indiana and recently expanded its role to include construction management services. The firm's portion of the program focuses on the sulfur-recovery complex.
Index Keywords: California; Capital budgets; Construction management; Consumer demands; Crude oil prices; Expansion projects; Financial crisis; Fluid catalytic cracking unit; Hydrotreaters; Indiana; Louisiana; McMurray; Memphis; Modernization projects; Oil producers; Oil production; Petroleum sectors; Storage facilities; Budget control; Cracking (chemical); Crude petroleum; Petroleum industry; Petroleum prospecting; Petroleum refining; Project management; Refining; Sulfur; Fluid catalytic cracking

Title: Membrane integrity, energy status and motility of rabbit spermatozoa stored for 2 days at 15°C
Affiliations: Department of Biotechnology of Animal Reproduction, National Research Institute of Animal Production, 32-083 Balicen, Krakow, Poland
Authors with affiliations: Gogol, P., Department of Biotechnology of Animal Reproduction, National Research Institute of Animal Production, 32-083 Balicen, Krakow, Poland; Ierzchoś-Hilczer, A.W., Department of Biotechnology of Animal Reproduction, National Research Institute of Animal Production, 32-083 Balicen, Krakow, Poland
Abstract: The effects of semen storage on membrane functional integrity, ATP content and motility of rabbit spermatozoa were investigated. The ejaculates were diluted with a commercial rabbit semen extender Galap. Semen was stored at 15°C and changes in quality were evaluated after 2, 24 and 48 hours of preservation. Membrane integrity was assessed with the HOS test and ATP content using a bioluminescence method. The time of storage had a significant effect on all studied parameters. However, motility and ATP content were significantly more affected than membrane integrity. After 48-h of preservation, sperm motility percentage and ATP content dramatically decreased by over 50%, while percentage of spermatozoa positively reacting to the HOS test decreased by approximately 14%. A significant correlation was found between the percentage of motile spermatozoa and intracellular ATP content (r = 0.59). HOS test score was correlated with neither sperm motility percentage nor sperm ATP content. The present results indicate that compared to membrane integrity, assessed with the HOS test, sperm ATP content and motility are more sensitive indicators of the effect of storage time on rabbit semen. The significant correlation between ATP content and the percentage of motile spermatozoa indicates that ATP assessment may be useful as an additional, objective laboratory test.
Author Keywords: ATP; HOS test; Rabbit; Semen storage; Sperm motility

Authors: Mengotti E., Heyderman L.J., Bisig A., Fraile Rodríguez A., Le Guyader L., Nolting F., Braun H.B.
Title: Dipolar energy states in clusters of perpendicular magnetic nanoislands
Affiliations: Paul Scherrer Institut, 5232 Villigen PSI, Switzerland; School of Physics, University College Dublin, Belfield, National University of Ireland, Dublin 4, Ireland
Authors with affiliations: Mengotti, E., Paul Scherrer Institut, 5232 Villigen PSI, Switzerland; Heyderman, L.J., Paul Scherrer Institut, 5232 Villigen PSI, Switzerland; Bisig, A., Paul Scherrer Institut, 5232 Villigen PSI, Switzerland; Fraile Rodríguez, A., Paul Scherrer Institut, 5232 Villigen PSI, Switzerland; Le Guyader, L., Paul Scherrer Institut, 5232 Villigen PSI, Switzerland; Nolting, F., Paul Scherrer Institut, 5232 Villigen PSI, Switzerland; Braun, H.B., School of Physics, University College Dublin, Belfield, National University of Ireland, Dublin 4, Ireland
Abstract: We investigated the energy states in compact clusters of ferromagnetic islands with perpendicular anisotropy arranged on a triangular lattice. Due to their finite nature, we were able to determine the energies of all possible cluster states using dipolar energy calculations. We employed photoemission electron microscopy to observe the magnetic states in arrays of clusters of monodomain Co/Pt multilayer islands and following demagnetization, we observed a shift in the energy distribution to lower energies as the dipolar coupling increased. These multistate island clusters not only provide model arrangements of frustrated Ising-type nanomagnets but are also interesting for data storage applications. © 2009 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Vasetsky Y., Mazurenko I., Aristov Y.
Title: Thin toroidal superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) with tilted coils: Dimension and mass parameters, stray magnetic fields
Affiliations: Institute of Electrodynamics, National Academy of Sciences of Ukraine, 56, Peremogy Avenue, 03680, Klev-57, Ukraine
Authors with affiliations: Vasetsky, Y., Institute of Electrodynamics, National Academy of Sciences of Ukraine, 56, Peremogy Avenue, 03680, Klev-57, Ukraine; Mazurenko, I., Institute of Electrodynamics, National Academy of Sciences of Ukraine, 56, Peremogy Avenue, 03680, Klev-57, Ukraine; Aristov, Y., Institute of Electrodynamics, National Academy of Sciences of Ukraine, 56, Peremogy Avenue, 03680, Klev-57, Ukraine
Abstract: In this paper the results of parametric analysis of toroidal superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) with tilted coils is considered. Volumes of superconducting winding and structural materials of support system as well as dimensions of magnetic system are examined. The results are obtained for mathematical modei as a current surface with the infinite number of the elliptic current filaments tilted to vertical axis of thin torus. Estimations of the stray magnetic fields as a function of distances, tilt angles and relative size of torus are obtained. Possibility of considerable reduction of volume of the structural materials and simultaneous some reduction of dimensions of the magnetic system and volume ofthe superconducting winding are shown.

Source title: Physics Letters, Section A: General, Atomic and Solid State Physics

Abstract: Using density functional theory and molecular dynamics we found that N-decorated single walled (8, 0) carbon nanotubes are potential high capacity hydrogen storage media. This system could store up to 6.0 wt% hydrogen at 300 K and ambient pressure, with average adsorption energy of -80 meV/(H2). Nitrogen coverage was C8N. © 2009 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

Title: Two charges laid against sunrise propane
Abstract: In August 2009, the Ontario Ministry of Labour laid two charges against the Sunrise Propane Energy Group under the Occupational Health and Safety Act. The Ministry's charges cite Sunrise's failure to protect the health and safety of a worker and to ensure the north Toronto propane facility was operating in accordance with industry regulations. The Ministry alleges Sunrise failed to provide instruction and supervision on safe work practices and recognition of hazards associated with propane storage, dispensing and handling, and on appropriate emergency response to propane leaks. The company also failed to take the reasonable precaution of ensuring that a propane facility was installed and operated in accordance with regulatory requirements and safe industry practice. If convicted, Sunrise could face maximum fines of $500,000/count.

Title: Panasas storage solution drives dramatic performance improvement to accelerate core research
Authors with affiliations: Barclay, S.
Abstract: Panasas, Inc., a leading provider of high-performance storage for the world's most performance-intensive applications, announced that the Clemson University Computational Center for Mobility Systems (CU-CCMS) has chosen the Panasas ActiveStor(TM) parallel storage system to increase its research and innovation. CU-CCMS is a comprehensive computational engineering center dedicated to solve the most complex problems for the automotive, aviation, and energy industries. It uses massive-scale engineering simulation to help industry sponsors reduce development time, improve product quality and cost, and achieve success in the global marketplace. The system consists of 430 Sun blade servers, with 3,440 Intel Xeon processing cores and 14 terabytes (TB) of memory. The CU-CCMS system completed the LINPACK benchmark at 27.3 TFLOPS, or 27.3 trillion mathematical computations per second, which ranks it among the world's most powerful computer systems.

Title: EU and OPEC: On the same page of the book
Authors with affiliations: Hughes, S.
Abstract: A report on issues and topics discussed at the 6th Ministerial Meeting of the EU-OPEC Energy Dialogue covers global challenges; oil's importance with regard to the global economy; issues facing the global energy market, e.g., oil price volatility, industry investment, and the impact of the financial crisis; problems of speculation in the paper oil markets; link between oil prices and investment; impacts of climate change mitigation response measures on developing countries, with emphasis on those for oil producing countries; the importance of the development and deployment of cleaner fossil fuel technologies and carbon capture and storage; and the impact of biofuels on the refining industry.

Authors with affiliations: Ludwig, D.S.; Pollack, H.A.

Title: News: Research and development: MOL Technology to move
Abstract: Mitsui O.S.K. Lines Ltd plans to move its MOL Technology Research Centre from its current site in Nishikojiya, Ota Ward, Tokyo, to Aso Ward in Kawasald, Kanagawa Prefecture. The MOL Technology Research Centre has taken a proactive approach to analyzing vessel fuel oils and lubricants, developing a fuel oil pre-treatment device, research and development on CO2 reduction, and other R&D efforts to improve storage and transport technologies. The new center will be an environmentally-friendly research facility using energy-saving technologies such as solar energy, natural lighting, and an ice thermal storage system, using electricity to make ice at night, when demand for power is low, and then melting the ice for air conditioning.

Title: On the billing and management of the air conditioning loads in electric power networks
Affiliations: Electrical Engineering Department, College of Engineering and Petroleum, Kuwait University, P.O. Box 5969, Safat 13060, Kuwait
Authors with affiliations: Saied, M.M., Electrical Engineering Department, College of Engineering and Petroleum, Kuwait University, P.O. Box 5969, Safat 13060, Kuwait
Abstract: A model is presented for analyzing the impact of air conditioning load characteristics, such as daily cooling energy consumption, start time, and duration, on the overall economy of the power system. The article then suggests a tariff system aimed at encouraging customers with an air conditioning load to cooperate with the electric utilities toward saving energy, achieving diversity between the original load and the air conditioning component, applying cooling energy storage systems, and efficiently controlling the starting time and duration. A system of inverted energy blocks and an exponential penalty function are recommended in order to encourage the customer to operate the air conditioning during daily time intervals far from the customer's original peak. Both the combined maximum demand and the demand charge increase almost linearly with the p.u. energy consumption of the air conditioning load. If the cooling energy is taken over durations longer than 20 hr/day, the demand charge will be reduced to about 80%, based on the case in which the original and the air conditioning load are coincident. The more than proportional increase in the energy bill will encourage the customer to adopt some measures in order to save cooling energy. For a certain required air conditioning energy, the total monthly bill depends strongly on its staring time. The advantage of starting the air conditioning load before 0700 or after 2000 could be seen. With the shifting of the air conditioning load, the customer will realize that a monthly savings of up to approximately 17% can be achieved. The total monthly bill can fluctuate between a value in excess of $220,000 and approximately $150,000/month, depending on the way the air conditioning is operated. It could be found that there is a duration for which the total bill reaches a minimum with an optimal duration of 11.9 hr. The customer has to adjust the operation scenario of air conditioning such that the entire cooling load will take place during the off-peak period of the system's load curve. This will encourage the user to consider and check the feasibility of using cooling energy storage systems that can enable such shifting of the air conditioning load. It can be recognized that the proposed tariff structure can be an effective tool for implementing the recommendations of some utilities in this regard.
Author Keywords: Air conditioning; Demand-side management; Energy storage system; Load management; Peak demand reduction

Title: Flexural strengthening of reinforced concrete columns with near-surface-mounted FRP or stainless steel
Affiliations: Department of Civil Engineering, University of Patras, Greece; Department of Civil Engineering, Structural Materials Laboratory, University of Patras, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Bournas, D.A., Department of Civil Engineering, University of Patras, Greece; Triantafillou, T.C., Department of Civil Engineering, Structural Materials Laboratory, University of Patras, Greece
Abstract: This paper presents the results of a large-scale experimental program aiming to study the behavior of reinforced concrete (RC) columns under simulated seismic loading, strengthened in flexure (of crucial importance in capacity design) with different types and configurations of near-surface-mounted (NSM) reinforcing materials. The role of different parameters is examined by comparing lateral load-versus-displacement response characteristics (peak force, drift ratios, energy dissipation, and stiffness). Those parameters are as follows: carbon or glass fiber-reinforced polymers (FRP) versus stainless steel, configuration and amount of NSM reinforcement, confinement via local jacketing, and type of bonding agent (epoxy resin or mortar). The results demonstrate that NSM FRP and stainless steel reinforcement is a viable solution toward enhancing the flexural resistance of RC columns subjected to seismic loads. This is especially the case when the retrofitting scheme combines epoxy-bonded NSM bars with local confining jackets (provided in this study with textile-reinforced mortars [TRM]).
Author Keywords: Columns; Flexure; Near-surface-mounted reinforcement; Seismic retrofitting; Strengthening; Textile-reinforced mortar

Title: Carbon-nanostructured materials for energy generation and storage applications
Affiliations: South African Institute for Advanced Materials Chemistry, University of the Western Cape, Private Bag X17, Bellville 7535, Cape Town, South Africa; Chemistry Department, Faculty of Natural Science, University of the Western Cape, Private Bag X17, Bellville 7535, Cape Town, South Africa
Authors with affiliations: Ndungu, P., South African Institute for Advanced Materials Chemistry, University of the Western Cape, Private Bag X17, Bellville 7535, Cape Town, South Africa, Chemistry Department, Faculty of Natural Science, University of the Western Cape, Private Bag X17, Bellville 7535, Cape Town, South Africa; Nechaev, A., South African Institute for Advanced Materials Chemistry, University of the Western Cape, Private Bag X17, Bellville 7535, Cape Town, South Africa; Khotseng, L., South African Institute for Advanced Materials Chemistry, University of the Western Cape, Private Bag X17, Bellville 7535, Cape Town, South Africa; Onyegebule, N., South African Institute for Advanced Materials Chemistry, University of the Western Cape, Private Bag X17, Bellville 7535, Cape Town, South Africa; Davids, W., South African Institute for Advanced Materials Chemistry, University of the Western Cape, Private Bag X17, Bellville 7535, Cape Town, South Africa; Mohammed, R., South African Institute for Advanced Materials Chemistry, University of the Western Cape, Private Bag X17, Bellville 7535, Cape Town, South Africa; Vaivars, G., South African Institute for Advanced Materials Chemistry, University of the Western Cape, Private Bag X17, Bellville 7535, Cape Town, South Africa; Linkov, V., South African Institute for Advanced Materials Chemistry, University of the Western Cape, Private Bag X17, Bellville 7535, Cape Town, South Africa
Abstract: We have developed and refined a chemical vapour deposition method to synthesise nanotubes using liquid petroleum gas as the carbon source. The nanotubes were thoroughly characterised by scanning electron microscopy, transmission electron microscopy, X-ray diffraction and thermogravimetric analysis. The protocol to grow nanotubes was then adapted to deposit nanotubes on the surface of different substrates, which were chosen based upon how the substrates could be applied in various hydrogen energy conversion systems. Carbon nanotubes are a nanostructured material with an extremely wide range of applications in various energy applications. The methods outlined demonstrate the complete development of carbon nanotube composite materials with direct applications in hydrogen energy generation, storage and conversion.

Authors: Verdonck L., Simpson D., Cornelis W.M., Plyson A., Bourgeois J., Docter R., van Meirvenne M.
Title: Ground-penetrating radar survey over bronze age circular monuments on a sandy soil, complemented with electromagnetic induction and fluxgate gradiometer data
Affiliations: Department of Archaeology, Ghent University, Blandijnberg 2, 9000 Ghent, Belgium; Department of Soil Management, Ghent University, Coupure Links 653, 9000 Ghent, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Verdonck, L., Department of Archaeology, Ghent University, Blandijnberg 2, 9000 Ghent, Belgium; Simpson, D., Department of Soil Management, Ghent University, Coupure Links 653, 9000 Ghent, Belgium; Cornelis, W.M., Department of Soil Management, Ghent University, Coupure Links 653, 9000 Ghent, Belgium; Plyson, A., Department of Archaeology, Ghent University, Blandijnberg 2, 9000 Ghent, Belgium; Bourgeois, J., Department of Archaeology, Ghent University, Blandijnberg 2, 9000 Ghent, Belgium; Docter, R., Department of Archaeology, Ghent University, Blandijnberg 2, 9000 Ghent, Belgium; van Meirvenne, M., Department of Soil Management, Ghent University, Coupure Links 653, 9000 Ghent, Belgium
Abstract: This paper presents aground-penetrating radar (GPR) survey over two circular structures originally surrounding Bronze Age burial mounds at the site of Koekel are (western Belgium). The region is characterized by sandy soils. Their low water storage capacity and the consequent moisture contrasts in dry summers played an important role in the detection of over1000 Bronze Age funeral monuments through aerial archaeology in the past few decades. At Koekelare, low attenuation of GPR waves resulted in the detection of a double and single circular ditch. A flux gate gradiometer survey and electromagnetic induction (EMI) measurements did not clearly reveal the ditches. For the GPR wave velocity analysis, constant velocity migration tests were combined with time-domain reflectometry(TDR). The TDR measurements were made at different depths within the ditches and in the adjacent undisturbed soil, so that the differences in the physical soil parameters could be assessed. At a depth of approximately 0.45 to 0.8 m, the relatively homogeneous ditch fill produces few GPR reflections compared with the undisturbed soil, and is visible as a weak negative anomaly on the horizontal slices. At this depth, the grey or brownish black ditch fill was found inaugering samples, clearly distinguishable from the yellowish brown sandy soil outside the ditches. The transition between the ditch and the underlying soil caused a gradual reflection of radar energy at a depth of approximately 0.8 to1.2 m, although TDR showed no marked differences in relative permittivity between the ditches and the surrounding soil, and no clear steps as a function of depth. © 2009 JohnWiley & Sons, Ltd.
Author Keywords: Aerial archaeology; Augering; Bronze age funeral monuments; Ground-penetrating radar; Time-domain reflectometry; Wave velocity analysis

Title: Coal ban could heat up electricity prices
Authors with affiliations: Pelley, J.
Abstract: The move to ban coal plants is a sharp turnaround from 2007, when, following a spike in natural gas prices, utilities proposed a 151 new coalfired power plants, according to the National Energy Technology Laboratory. In 2009, only 87 plants are under development because of uncertainty over climate change regulations. Governors in 13 states from California to Michigan and Florida have effectively halted construction of new conventional coal-fired power plants by rejecting permits outright or setting CO2 emission standards that would be impossible to meet without carbon capture and storage. According to Jay Apt, a physicist at Carnegie Mellon University, banning new coal generation will increase the consumption of natural gas. Modelling results show increases in natural gas use of 27-56% in Texas, 44-500% in the eastern US, and 92-500% in the Midwest. A doubling of natural gas demand would lead, in turn, to price increases ranging from 175 to 500%, according to the study.
Index Keywords: carbon dioxide; coal; chemistry; economics; electric power plant; electricity; greenhouse effect; legal aspect; note; policy; pollution; statistical model; time; United States; Carbon Dioxide; Coal; Electricity; Environmental Pollution; Greenhouse Effect; Models, Economic; Power Plants; Public Policy; Time Factors; United States

Title: Future opportunities for the energy ecosystem
Affiliations: Microsoft's Worldwide Utilities team
Authors with affiliations: Arnold, J., Microsoft's Worldwide Utilities team; Cochrane, L., Microsoft's Worldwide Utilities team
Abstract: Energy issues represent a challenging and complex societal problem that will take years and collaboration across all constituents in the industry to address. Utility energy management systems must boost capacity from 30 or 40 generators to 10 to 20 million generation sources, all asynchronously participating in grid behavior. Grid solutions will need the capability to handle Internet-scale data acquisition to control the growing number of devices. They will also need the scale to handle large, complex, real-time hierarchical network reliability solutions, as well as massive data storage and analysis. Companies can use synchrophasors to help measure the grid system's health, but if they run the network at its reliability limit, they will need new equipment and new techniques to make the grid more agile and resilient. Utilities will need new solutions based upon a smart, dynamic, integrated technology infrastructure that spans the utility value chain from fuels to the home.

Authors: Yamamoto T., Carrero J.J., Lindholm B., Stenvinkel P., Axelsson J.
Title: Leptin and uremic protein-energy wasting - The axis of eating
Affiliations: Divisions of Renal Medicine and Baxter Novum, Department of Clinical Science, Intervention and Technology, Karolinska Institutet, Stockholm, Sweden; Department of Clinical Science, Intervention and Technology, K56 Renal Medicine, Karolinska University Hospital Huddinge, 141 86, Stockholm, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Yamamoto, T., Divisions of Renal Medicine and Baxter Novum, Department of Clinical Science, Intervention and Technology, Karolinska Institutet, Stockholm, Sweden; Carrero, J.J., Divisions of Renal Medicine and Baxter Novum, Department of Clinical Science, Intervention and Technology, Karolinska Institutet, Stockholm, Sweden; Lindholm, B., Divisions of Renal Medicine and Baxter Novum, Department of Clinical Science, Intervention and Technology, Karolinska Institutet, Stockholm, Sweden; Stenvinkel, P., Divisions of Renal Medicine and Baxter Novum, Department of Clinical Science, Intervention and Technology, Karolinska Institutet, Stockholm, Sweden, Department of Clinical Science, Intervention and Technology, K56 Renal Medicine, Karolinska University Hospital Huddinge, 141 86, Stockholm, Sweden; Axelsson, J., Divisions of Renal Medicine and Baxter Novum, Department of Clinical Science, Intervention and Technology, Karolinska Institutet, Stockholm, Sweden
Abstract: Leptin, a regulator of eating behavior, is secreted by adipocytes and affects energy homeostasis in health and disease. Specifically, leptin is implicated in modulating multiple pathways controlling energy intake, energy expenditure and the allocation of precious nutrients between conversion, storage, and consumption. Whereas leptin has been shown to be a major determinant of anorexia in uremic animals, human data are so far unclear. Regardless, multiple studies have demonstrated that patients with chronic kidney function impairment have elevated leptin levels, although these levels still correlate strongly with body fat mass. In the present publication, we will review the current evidence for the pathophysiological role of leptin, focusing on chronic kidney disease (CKD) patients. © 2009 Wiley Periodicals, Inc.
Index Keywords: leptin; article; energy metabolism; food intake; human; metabolism; physiology; uremia; Appetite Regulation; Energy Metabolism; Humans; Leptin; Uremia

Title: Unlike the other Hanford production reactors, N Reactor served a dual purpose: It produced plutonium for nuclear weapons and steam for electricity
Abstract: Part of N Reactor at Hanford, the last of nine plutonium reactors to be shut down at the US Department of Energy's Hanford site, is being placed in interim safe storage in a process known as cocooning where it is expected to remain for up to 75 years. Cocooning involves demolition of each facility down to the four-foot-thick shield walls that surround the radioactive steam generators in the 109-N Building and the reactor core for N Reactor. A new roof named a safe storage enclosure is installed over the remaining structure and heat and moisture sensors are installed to monitor remotely for fire and water. Workers will periodically enter the cocooned facility to check on their condition and make the needed repairs. The N Reactor/109-N complex represents the sixth of the Hanford's nine reactors to be cocooned, while installation of N Reactor's cocoon roof and walls will begin in 2009 and complete in 2012.
Index Keywords: Hanford; Hanford site; Moisture sensors; Nuclear weapons; Safe storage; Shut down; US Department of Energy; Moisture control; Plant shutdowns; Plutonium; Radioactive wastes; Roofs; Walls (structural partitions); electricity generation; nuclear weapon; plutonium; radioactivity; storage; wall; Hanford; North America; United States; Washington [United States]

Title: Sensors - the best of sensors expo awards 2009: meet the winners!
Affiliations: Sensors
Authors with affiliations: Martella, M., Sensors
Abstract: The Best of Sensor Expo Awards at Sensor Expo 2009 awarded sixteen new products that offer impressive functionality, utility, and uniqueness. The gold award winner in Sensor category was 6DX miniature 6 degree-of-freedom sensor from DTS, California. MicroStrain Inc., won a gold in the data Acquisition products category for its HS-LINK high speed wireless sensor node, which is capable of acquiring bursts of synchronized data at sample rates up to 100 Ksps for three sensor channels. Infinite Power Solutions Inc., bagged silver award in the Sensors category for INFINERY Micro Power Module (MPM) energy storage device. Kionix Inc., New York, also won bronze award in Sensors category for KXTF9 triaxial MEMS accelerometer with Directional Tap/Double-Tap. Sensortecnics Inc., Miami, won Honorable mention in the Sensors category for its CLC capacitive level sensor.

Title: The increasingly troubled relationship between water and energy
Authors with affiliations: Parker, K.
Abstract: The World Economic Forum and CERA released a new report, entitled 'Thirsty Energy: water and energy in the 21st century' that addressed the problem of increasing use of water in energy production. The report revealed that water continued to remain essential for the energy industry, as it was needed for exploring and extracting fossil fuel reserves, including oil sands and natural gas. It was also found that the introduction and scale-up of carbon capture and storage increased water exposure of the energy sector. The report revealed that in older oil fields more water was produced in comparison with oil, leading to water scarcity. The findings of the report also revealed that the water produced from these contaminated and is unable to be released without proper treatment. It suggested that the industry need to find new water sources for use in production and solve disposal problems related to produced water, as it continued to focus on enhanced oil recovery (EOR).

Title: Forward to the past
Authors with affiliations: Sheble, G.
Abstract: The future of the energy industry in the US with respect to microgrids, generators, wind turbines, and solar cells is discussed. The US aims to install various distributed generators, such as wind turbines and solar cells, with an increased national grid with energy efficient use. The distributed generation concept is forwarding the system design into isolated microgrids. The advent of micropumped hydro storage enables new installations to be as cost effective as microgrids. The implementation of smart-grid solutions is now focusing on facilitating the implementation of distributed generation, such as solar cells and small wind turbines. The advent of high voltage direct current (HVDC) light for distribution applications provides extensive isolation of power systems at various distributed levels. Continuous pre-balancing of each microgrid enables extended controls to facilitate fast circuit breakers, FACTS, and HVDC interactions to improve system reliability in an economic fashion.
Index Keywords: Circuit breaker; Cost effective; Distributed Generation; Distributed generators; Energy efficient use; Energy industry; High voltage direct current; Micro grid; National Grid; Power systems; Small wind turbine; System design; System reliability; Electric generators; Electric inverters; Electric potential; Energy efficiency; Engines; Mesh generation; Photovoltaic cells; Power generation; Solar cells; Wind power; Wind turbines; Solar energy

Title: Process news: Modular nuclear reactor stores lifetime of fuel
Abstract: Babcock & Wilcox (B&W) has designed a new 125 Mw nuclear reactor, which will ease concerns surrounding scale-up, grid connectivity, and safety. The modular design of its advanced light water reactor, named as the mPower reactor, will allow customers to increase electricity output in 125 Mw increments depending on local energy needs and the limitations of the site and the power grid it is connecting to. This flexibility could attract small municipal districts, buyers in developing countries where the transmission systems cannot handle conventional larger reactors, and could even draw the attention of industrial users with independent on-site generation needs. This potential decentralization and expansion of nuclear power and the fuel and waste that goes with it is likely to cause concern but according to B&W, its onsite fuel containment concept should diminish fears and minimize licensing challenges. The reactors are designed to be contained below ground with sufficient storage space to hold enough new and spent fuel to last its 60-yr lifespan. The design will be operated for 5 yr on one batch of fuel and this cut the cost of operating the plant. Construction of the first unit could begin as early as 2015, and start producing electricity in 2018.

Title: Analysis: €4b injection for European energy projects
Abstract: The European Commission (EC) is offering $5.6 billion to developers of carbon capture and storage (CCS) technology, offshore wind energy, and gas and electricity infrastructure. Under the European Energy Programme for Recovery, developers have until 7/15/2009 to submit proposals, and the EC expects to begin handing out the first of the funds to successful applicants by the end of the year. The financing will speed up investments in the energy sector and have a direct impact on the EU economy and on employment. It will also help to improve the security of supply of the most vulnerable member states. The funding will also assist in speeding up the implementation of the 20/20/20 objectives (to reduce carbon emissions and energy consumption by 20%, and increase renewable energy use by 20%, all by 2020) by promoting for the first time on a large scale the development of CCS technologies and the implementation of high power wind turbines.

Title: Depth charge
Authors with affiliations: McCulley, R.
Abstract: The Houston Advanced Research Center (HARC) has begun the groundwork for developing seafloor power systems to explore the business prospects in seafloor power generation at deepwater Gulf of Mexico oil fields. The center plans to demarcate two or three concepts from a diverse field of technologies, generate plans for prototypes and gain an understanding of the environmental impacts of the finalists. The technologies that will be finally accepted will have to be capable of producing sizeable energy. As per April status report, the list of the power conversion technologies under deliberation include: proton-exchange membrane fuel cells powered with hydrogen and oxygen; fuel cells; small pressurized water nuclear reactors; ocean current-powered turbines on the sea floor; and wind and wave power. The HARC team is also examining numerous energy storage strategies such as compressed gas storage; liquid redox batteries; pressure-tolerant secondary batteries; and other nonconventional battery systems.

Authors: Cosemans S., Dehaene W., Catthoor F.
Title: A 3.6 pJ/access 480 MHz, 128 kb on-chip SRAM with 850 MHz boost mode in 90 nm CMOS with tunable sense amplifiers
Affiliations: ESAT, MICAS Laboratory, Katholieke Universiteit Leuven, B-3001 Leuven, Belgium; IMEC, NES, B-3001 Leuven, Belgium; Katholieke Universiteit Leuven, B-3001 Leuven, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Cosemans, S., ESAT, MICAS Laboratory, Katholieke Universiteit Leuven, B-3001 Leuven, Belgium; Dehaene, W., ESAT, MICAS Laboratory, Katholieke Universiteit Leuven, B-3001 Leuven, Belgium; Catthoor, F., IMEC, NES, B-3001 Leuven, Belgium, Katholieke Universiteit Leuven, B-3001 Leuven, Belgium
Abstract: An extremely low energy per operation, single cycle 32 bit/word, 128 kb SRAM is fabricated in 90 nm CMOS. In the 850 MHz boost mode, total energy consumption is 8.4 pJ/access. This reduces to 3.6 pJ/access in the normal 480 MHz mode and bottoms out at a very aggressive 2.7 pJ/access in the 240 MHz low power mode. Several techniques were combined to obtain these performance numbers. Short buffered local bit lines reduce the impact of the cell read current on memory delay. Extended global bitlines are used which improves delay and energy consumption and which reduces the number of sense amplifiers in the memory to 32. Cell stability and speed issues are avoided by applying selective voltage scaling. Novel, digitally tunable sense amplifiers and a tunable timing circuit cope gracefully with the stochastic variations in the periphery. © 2006 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Bit line hierarchy; Calibrated timing; Dynamic cell stability; Embedded memory; Low-power; Selective voltage scaling; Sense amplifier calibration; SRAM; Variability-aware design

Title: Refining: Southern Africa: Keeping the supply lines open
Authors with affiliations: Sayila, A.
Abstract: The Tanzania-Zambia (TAZAMA) transnational oil pipeline and Indeni oil refinery at Ndola, Zambia, act as important supply links for petroleum products to countries in southern Africa. Recognizing their importance, rehabilitation works were commissioned at both facilities to improve their performance and increase their efficiency. According to the Zambian Minister of Energy Kenneth Kongan, new oil storage facilities are also under construction at all provincial capitals at a cost of some $41 million, which will have the capacity to store some 2 million L of fuel. The government is geared to increase fuel storage for both local consumption and export to neighboring countries. Kongan also disclosed that his government, in partnership with Total International, has committed a further $65 million to the Indeni oil refinery for its recapitalization over the next 5 yr. The government is determined to modernize and expand the oil refinery's activities to meet growing demand for petroleum products in the region, which is forecast to reach 150,000 L/day in 2010.

Title: Regeneration of sodium borohydride from sodium metaborate, and isolation of intermediate compounds
Affiliations: Industrial Research Limited, PO Box 31310, Lower Hutt, 5040, New Zealand; MacDiarmid Institute for Advanced Materials and Nanotechnology, PO Box 600, Wellington, 6140, New Zealand
Authors with affiliations: Kemmitt, T., Industrial Research Limited, PO Box 31310, Lower Hutt, 5040, New Zealand, MacDiarmid Institute for Advanced Materials and Nanotechnology, PO Box 600, Wellington, 6140, New Zealand; Gainsford, G.J., Industrial Research Limited, PO Box 31310, Lower Hutt, 5040, New Zealand
Abstract: A method for the regeneration of sodium borohydride from its hydrolysis product, sodium borate, is described. The dried borate salt was converted to a series of sodium tetraalkoxyborates prior to reaction with NaAlH4 in refluxing diglyme to regenerate sodium borohydride. At room temperature in tetrahydrofuran, the same reactants formed the partial hydrides NaBH3(OR) (R = C1-4 alkyl). Products were characterised by multinuclear 1H, 13C, 11B and 27Al NMR studies. The intermediate alkoxyborate products were confirmed by single crystal X-ray structural studies. © 2009 International Association for Hydrogen Energy.
Author Keywords: Hydride regeneration; Hydrogen storage; Sodium borohydride
