Title: Nanostructured Materials for Energy Storage and Conversion
Abstract: The proceedings contain 15 papers. The topics discussed include: application of layered nickel double hydroxide for alkali secondary battery using the liquid phase deposition method; anodic oxidation of hydrogen in PEFCs at varying platinum loadings; characteristics of gallium doped ZnO thin films deposited by sol gel dip coating; electro-oxidation of methanol by multi-metal catalysts supported on carbon nanotubes; novel nanocomposites polymethacrylate hydroxyethylene resin based electrolyte; synthesis of Pt nano electrocatalyst for methanol oxidation using polymer template; synthesis and characterization of monolayer bimetallic surfaces: a synchrotron NEXAFS and XPS study; polyaniline coated active carbon as binary catalysts support for direct methanol fuel cell; and metal oxide nano-particles and nano-composite polymer electrolytes - electrodes and electrolytes in solar and galvanic cells of the second generation.

Title: Hydrogen Production, Transport, and Storage 3
Abstract: The proceedings contain 10 papers. The topics discussed include: solid oxide membrane electrolyzer utilizing the energy value in solid and gaseous reductant for hydrogen production; materials challenges in hydrogen production from hydrocarbons; CuCl-HCI electrolyzer for hydrogen production via Cu-Cl thermochemical cycle; preparation and hydrogen storage performance of Pd nanoparticles decorated carbon nanotubes; time dependent analysis of a metal hydride bed; synthesis of micro-porous boron-substituted carbon (B/C) materials using polymeric precursors for hydrogen physisorption; effect of SO2 crossover on hydrogen and sulfuric acid production in a PEM electrolyzer; hydrogen generation from alkaline solutions of methanol and ethanol by electrolysis; and low temperature electrochemical production of hydrogen from the hybrid copper-chlorine thermochemical cycle.

Title: Americas: Stimulus cash for 'transformational' power
Abstract: The DOE announced 37 energy research projects to receive a slice of the $400 million Advanced Research Projects program. The 37 successful projects were whittled down from a total of 3600 entries, and will share $151 million of funding. The program, part of president Obama's green economic stimulus, supports transformational technologies that overcomes climate change and energy security concerns. Carbon capture and storage processes featured heavily among the successful projects, as well as advanced batteries and more efficient lighting. Examples include the liquid metal grid-scale batteries, which is an all-liquid metal battery based on cheap, domestically-available liquid metals. The batteries could make large-scale energy storage an integral part of the nation's energy grid, enabling intermittent power, e.g., wind and solar, to be used around-the-clock and increasing the stability of the grid.

Title: United Kingdom: SSE eyes pumped storage scheme
Abstract: Scottish and Southern Energy (SSE) hopes to win the permission it needs to build the UK's first large-scale pumped storage hydroelectric scheme in over 30 yr. SSE will submit a planning application in 2011 to build two 300-600 Mw schemes on the north side of Scotland's Great Glen. The technology could help smooth the peaks and troughs in energy demand that make it difficult to scale up inherently intermittent renewables such as wind power beyond a certain level. Each scheme would require two bodies of water at differing heights. SSE plans to buy electricity to pump water uphill during periods of low demand and release it downhill through turbines when demand is high, effectively turning the dam into a giant battery.

Title: ABS gives preliminary approval to second offshore gas to liquids concept
Abstract: ABS has issued an Approval in Principle (AIP) for a second floating Gas to Liquids (GTL) concept and is reviewing several additional GTL concepts from leading energy operators. ABS provided its first AIP for a GTL concept (a floating production barge facility) in 2006. Since then, it has seen a steady increase in requests from designers for review and preliminary assessment of proprietary technologies. By placing the GTL plant on an existing floating production, storage, and offloading vessels (FPSO), associated gas that would have been flared or re-injected can be converted to a clean, low-sulfur petroleum product or blended into oil, transferred using conventional FPSO handling systems and shuttled ashore using readily available product tanker tonnage. The key is to test minimal-scale GTL plants onshore to verify technology and identify all potential risk.

Title: UK: Natural gas to plug energy gap
Abstract: UK has commissioned three new gas-fired power stations to add nearly 4 Gw of capacity to the grid. Powerfuel, which is majority-owned by Russian coal company KRU, is to construct an 800 Mw combined-cycle gas-turbine (CCGT) station in Yorkshire, northern England, by 2012. It plans to convert the plant to a 900 Mw integrated-gasification combined-cycle (IGCC) power station by 2014, to produce near-zero carbon emissions, using coal from the company's Hatfield colliery. The government argues this new capacity is needed to fill the gap before other low-carbon power sources, such as nuclear and wind power, can replace ageing coal-fired and nuclear facilities. The firms have agreed that the power stations will be designed so that carbon capture and storage technology can be retrofitted, should that become viable in future. Shell, would capture around 90% of potential carbon emissions.

Title: North America: United States: AGL Resources...
Abstract: Pivotal Energy Development is constructing a $310 million, two-cavern, 24 bcf underground gas-storage facility in Texas. The first cavern is scheduled for completion in 2010, the second in 2012.

Title: Emission impossible
Abstract: Thousands of officials, advisors, and diplomats representing the 192 countries that are the signatories to the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change met on 12/7-18/2009 in Copenhagen, Denmark. Their job is to agree a successor to the Framework's Kyoto Protocol by setting emissions targets beyond 2012 they hope to stabilize atmospheric carbon concentrations and prevent human activities from driving climate change to dangerous levels. Danger in this case is a 2°C rise in global warming above pre-industrial levels - a rise widely thought to have "catastrophic" consequences. If mankind is to remain safe, climate scientists have advised politicians to ration humanity to emitting no more than 1400b ton of CO2 equivalent between 2000 and 2050. Sticking to this carbon diet requires global emissions to peak no later than 2015 and to fall by 25-40% below 1990 levels by 2020 and 80% by 2050. According to China, it will cut emissions per unit of GDP by 40-45% on 2005 levels by 2020. It plans to aggressively expand into renewable energies, nuclear power, and carbon capture and storage. However, US president Barack Obama promises to reduce emissions 4% below 1990 levels by 2020.

Title: Transportation - Quick takes: Nippon to lease domestic oil tanks to ADNOC
Abstract: Nippon Oil Corp has reached a final agreement with Abu Dhabi National Oil Co (ADNOC) for the UAE firm to store oil in an effort to bolster Japan's national reserves. ADNOC will store 3.9 million bbl of crude for 3 yr at a reserve base in Kagoshima Prefecture, Japan. The basic agreement, which will allow storage equal to a day's consumption for Japan, initially was announced in June 2009, and is expected to help improve the Asian nation's energy security. The agreement also would give Japan a preferential right to purchase the stored oil reserves there in times of emergency. The scheme will also allow Abu Dhabi to sell its oil in other East Asian countries, e.g., South Korea and Taiwan, by using the Japanese base as a distribution terminal.

Title: Government: South Korea to build oil hub for Northeast Asia
Abstract: South Korea's refiners SK Energy and GS Caltex Corp, along with Korea National Oil Corp (KNOC), are setting up a joint venture (JV) to transform the country's southern coastal area into an oil hub for Northeast Asia, with a combined storage capacity of 28 million bbl. The JV would include foreign companies such as Glencore. In the first stage, the JV plans to spend $320 million to turn Yeosu, a southern industrial city and home to the country's second-largest refiner GS Caltex, into an oil hub with a capacity to store 6 million barrels of oil by December 2011. The second stage involves building a storage facility with a capacity of about 22 million bbl in Ulsan, another southern industrial city and home to the country's biggest refiner 5K Energy, and Hyundai Heavy Industries, the world's largest maker of oil and gas carriers.

Title: News in brief: North America: United States: Haddington Energy Partners III...
Abstract: Haddington Energy Partners III and GE Energy Financial Services have begun operations at the Bobcat salt cavern gas-storage facility in St. Landry Parish, LA. The site's initial capacity is almost 5.4 bcf of working gas, which is scheduled to be increased to 10.3 bcf by the third quarter of 2009 and to 15.6 bcf by year-end 2009.

Title: LDH energy and explorer pipeline plan storage/pipeline connection
Abstract: Louis Dreyfus Highbridge Energy LLC (LDH Energy) and Explorer Pipeline Co plans to make connections from LDH Energy's Mont Belvieu, TX, storage facility to Explorer's 28-in. pipeline system. The connection will be designed to accommodate movements of refined products and natural gasoline. The parties expect the connection to be operational in the fourth quarter of 2010.

Title: US: Opening the season for proposed LaCrosse pipeline
Abstract: Enbridge is carrying out a binding open season for its LaCrosse pipeline, which has been designed to carry gas from Carthage, TX, to multiple delivery points in southeast Louisiana. Construction of the proposed 547-km pipeline will take place in two phases. During Phase I, Enbridge will construct and commission the 42- and 36-in.dia pipeline sections running from its Carthage hub to Point Coupee Parish, LA, and a 24-in. section from Point Coupee Parish to Petrologistics' Choctaw storage facility in Iberville Parish, LA. In the second phase, Enbridge will construct and bring into service the pipeline section from Point Coupee to an interconnection with Southern Natural Gas Co in Washington Parish, LA. The planned commissioning dates will be phased to meet commercial demand between January 2012 and March 2013. Enbridge Energy Co is in the process of negotiating third party agreements that will bring total capacity commitments to exceed 1 billion cu ft/day, and have additional indications of interest that could exceed 1.3 billion cu ft/day.

Title: News in brief: Western Europe: United Kingdom: Gateway Storage, managed...
Abstract: Gateway Storage, managed by Stag Energy, has won approvals from the Department of Energy and Climate Change to construct a 1.5 billion cu m gas storage facility in the east Irish Sea. Subsea salt caverns some 15 mi off Barrow-in-Furness will be connected to the gas grid through a compressor station, to be constructed adjacent to the Morecambe gas terminals. Start-up is targeted for 2014.

Title: Canada: Alberta Clipper and Southern Lights go ahead
Abstract: Enbridge can now proceed with construction of the Canadian portion of its $3-billion Alberta Clipper pipeline, which will carry 450,000 bpd of oilsands crude to the US. The National Energy Board attached a few conditions to its approval, including a requirement that Enbridge test its emergency response procedures at the point where the line crosses the South Saskatchewan River. The 1607-km Alberta Clipper line will run from the storage hub at Hardisty, Alberta, to Superior, WI, from where oil will distributed to other pipelines and refiners in the US' Midwest and elsewhere. Anticipated to be in service by the middle of 2010, the line is one of a number being planned to handle a massive increase in Canadian oil exports to the US as production from the oilsands expands. Enbridge has also received approval of its $2.2-billion Southern Lights pipeline project, which will ship diluent from the US Midwest to northern Alberta for oilsands development. The new pipeline will carry 180,000 brl/d of diluent - light hydrocarbons used to dilute oilsands syncrude enough to allow it to flow through pipelines - and will involve laying nearly 1100 km of new pipe, reversing the flow in some existing lines, and using other existing facilities.

Title: Natural gas: United States: Gas market in flux
Abstract: According to EIA, while the seasonal boost in natural gas consumption is expected to add some strength to prices, robust storage levels are expected to limit any significant upward price movement through the winter, forecasting a fall of 1.9% in US natural gas consumption in 2009. The US Natural Gas Supply Association, which estimates that gas from shale plays supplied 10-12% of US gas demand in 2008, says the contribution of the resource to national supply could double in the next 10 years, meeting a quarter of the country's demand. Ziff Energy Group predicts gas production in North America from shale, coal seams, and tight sandstones will reach 46 bcf/day by 2020 - more than twice the 2000 total. According to Petroleum Economist's LNG Data Centre, there is around 70 million ton/yr of LNG-import capacity and as much again due for completion by around 2011. However, 480 bcf is the equivalent of just over 9 million ton/yr.

Title: News: Environmental protection: IEA calls for massive investments in carbon capture
Abstract: According to the International Energy Agency (IEA), the world will need to set up 100 CO2 capture and underground storage projects by 2020 to ensure that the fight against climate change remains affordable. IEA's roadmap says that between $2.5 trillion and $3 trillion of additional investment will be needed worldwide within the next 4 decades to launch the technology commercially. This would require building 100 demonstration projects by 2020 and over 3000 by 2050. The challenge will be to integrate those individual stages of carbon capture and storage (CCS) that have already proved technically viable and to scale them up. The IEA calls on developed countries to make available $1.5 billion-$2.5 billion to fund CCS demonstration in developing countries. It stresses that the short timeframe and the massive scale of investment required make wide international collaboration indispensable. Big investments in CCS are already planned in OECD countries. Norway, which announced a most ambitious emission reduction target of 40% by 2020 during the latest round of climate talks in Bangkok, would almost double its budget for CCS in 2010. The US is earmarking over $4 billion for CO2 capture, a figure which is to be matched by $7 billion from the industry.

Title: Petroleum Economist: Exploration and production: Equatorial Guinea: Aseng go-ahead opens up eastern waters
Abstract: The July 2009 official sanction for Noble Energy's development of the Aseng field marks the start of development work in a new province to the east of Bioko island. In its first development project in Africa, Noble is to use a floating production, storage and offloading (FPSO) vessel and five subsea wells to bring Aseng on stream in mid-2012. Production should start at 50,000 bpd, with gas reinjected for pressure maintenance in the first phase of the project. Recoverable reserves are estimated at 100 million-120 million bbl of liquids and 12.7 billion-15.6 billion cu m of gas. Cost of the development is put at $1.3 billion, excluding the cost of the FPSO, which will be leased.

Title: Western Europe: United Kingdom: Scottish & Southern Energy...
Abstract: Scottish & Southern Energy and StatoilHydro started operations at their Aldbrough gas-storage facility, on the UK's east coast and close to the Easington gas-import terminal for the Langeled pipeline from Norway. Initial capacity is 60 m cu m in two caverns, but three more caverns are due to be available by the end of 2010. By 2012, Aldbrough is planned to be the UK's largest facility with a storage capacity of 370 million cu m and a delivery capacity of 40 million cu m/day.

Title: News: Great Britain: Start of operations at Aldbrough gas storage
Abstract: StatoilHydro and Scottish and Southern Energy have started some commercial operations at the Aldbrough gas storage facility in East Yorkshire, UK. Initially, Aldbrough will provide around 60 million cu m of capacity in two caverns. Capacity in another three caverns is expected to become available by the end of 2010 and the facility is an important contribution to further build UK'S gas storage capacity. When fully commissioned, Aldbrough will have the capacity to store up to 370 million cu m in nine underground caverns and will be the largest onshore gas storage facility in the UK. It will deliver gas to the National Transmission System at a rate of 40 million cu m/day and have up to 30 million cu m/day of gas injected.

Title: Michels completes crucial water crossings on Rex pipeline project
Abstract: According to the FERC, the Kinder-Morgan's Rockies Express (REX) Pipeline is the largest currently under construction and members of the Commission have unofficially dubbed it, "The King of Pipelines". REX is a joint development of Kinder-Morgan Energy Partners LP and Sempra Pipelines & Storage. Once completed, the 42-in. pipeline will extend almost 1700 mi, from Rio Blanco County, CO, to Monroe County, OH. A discussion covers the completion of four deepwater bores on the project; tie-in on Blackburn Island; potential risk of environmental contamination to the surrounding, populated areas; drilling challenges; directional crossings; and pipeline capacity, e.g., opportunity to access a new and plentiful source of Rocky Mountain gas at a rate of ∼ 2 bcf/day.

Title: Back to the drawing board for Europe's energy diversification plans
Abstract: A discussion on Europe's energy diversification plans covers the gas dispute between Russia and Ukraine; growth in the demand for natural gas; the European Commission's calls for additional capacity to receive LNG, better interconnections between EU states, and more storage facilities; proposed LNG terminals that could make a difference to the areas most at risk from future supply disruptions arising from the annual Russia-Ukraine argument; reluctance of buyers in Europe's semi-liberalised market to match the levels paid by Asian consumers; concerns with the Nabucco pipeline; Gazprom's own two pipeline proposals, i.e., Nord Stream through the Baltic Sea and South Stream into Nabucco's proposed market in Central Europe; and environmental concerns.

Title: Dubai: New energy bodies to manage supply security
Abstract: Dubai has set up two new authorities to oversee its energy sector, amid concerns that the emirate's growing reliance on imports will leave it exposed to energy shortages. A new Supreme Energy Council will coordinate exploration, production, storage, transport, and distribution of natural gas, gas liquids, petroleum products, and crude oil, as well as services related to these activities. A separate Department of Petroleum Affairs will monitor the production, sale and export of crude, which has declined to around 70,000 bpd. The Supreme Energy Council will act as a regulatory authority and will also advise the Dubai government on keeping its power plants running, by ensuring there are sufficient gas imports. It will also be tasked with drawing up an energy strategy for Dubai, which will be reviewed every 3 yr. The council will set tariffs and determine the level and source of government subsidies on energy and review existing contracts with regional and international companies. The council will comprise representatives from Dubai Electricity and Water Authority, Dubai Aluminum, Emirates National Oil, Dubai Petroleum, the Dubai Nuclear Energy Committee, Dubai Supply Authority and the Department for Petroleum Affairs. Dusup, the state-owned body responsible for gas supply, will start LNG imports in 2010 through a floating regasification facility, which will supplement existing supplies during the peak-demand summer months. Shell will source the LNG from Qatargas 4 project. The UAE is planning a civil nuclear energy program to ensure energy supplies and reduce its dependence on gas. By 2017, the federation expects to have built 40 Gw of nuclear generating capacity.

Title: Company to offer gas storage in July
Abstract: Monroe Gas Storage Company LLC, a joint venture of Foothills Energy Ventures LLC and High Sierra Energy LP, announced a binding open season for up to 1 bcf of firm, high deliverability storage capacity at its Monroe Gas Storage facility currently under construction near the city of Amory, MS. The Monroe facility will use a depleted natural gas reservoir to provide multi-cycle natural gas storage with a maximum injection capability of 445,000 cu ft/dat and a maximum withdrawal capability of 465,000 cu ft/day. The project will have dual interconnections to Texas Eastern Transmission Company in the M1 market zone and Tennessee Gas Pipeline into the 500 Leg in Zone 1. The company expects the capacity to be available beginning 7/1/2009.

Title: North America: Canada: A Canadian Energy Research Institute...
Abstract: According to a Canadian Energy Research Institute study, crude prices must reach a minimum economic threshold of $90/bbl before oil-sands producers will invest in technology to reduce greenhouse-gas emissions, such as gasification of coal and petroleum coke to produce heat and steam, nuclear power, and carbon capture and storage. The study also said Alberta government penalties on excess CO2 emissions will have to rise from $(Can)15/ton to $(Can)65/ton before the industry will invest in the technology rather than pay the levies.

Title: Tankers of the 21st: Feature 1: Rising to the regas challenge
Abstract: The first LNG delivery to involve Golar Spirit since its conversion from a gas tanker to a floating storage and regasification unit took place at the Petrobras gas import facility in Pecem, Brazil, on 1/18-26/2009. The ship, the first of what will eventually be three conversions for Golar LNG, represents the first vessel to have regasification plant retrofitted. The Exxcelerate system is capable of regasifying ∼ 14 million cu m/day of LNG, allows discharge of LNG at 35-100 bar. The regasification plant was designed around a set of shell and tube type vaporizers. The use of shell and tube vaporizers has several important advantages for offshore applications, e.g., compact, simple to operate, energy efficient, and are not affected by ship's motions.

Title: Australia: Wandoan jv plans "groundbreaking" IGCC with CCS
Abstract: GE Energy, Xstrata, and Stanwell Power plan to construct the world's first integrated gasification combined-cycle power plant that will also capture and store 90% of its CO2. The 400 Mw plant would be located alongside Xstrata's proposed Wandoan open-cut coal mine in Queensland's Surat Basin and begin commercial operations by 2016. The Wandoan partners want to capture CO2 from the fuel stream only, not from flue gases. The compressed CO2 would be injected in one of several potential storage options near the proposed project site. These sites will be evaluated further during the next phase of feasibility studies.

Title: Time to walk the diversification walk
Abstract: The January 2009 contractual dispute between Russia and Ukraine will compel Europe to make greater efforts to diversify its natural gas supplies and to move away from gas as an energy source. The bust-up was the result of the usual problems, i.e., the level of future gas prices and alleged late payment of bills. There were similarities and differences with the January 2006 dispute. Ukraine was better prepared - it had stored enough gas to put up with a lengthy stoppage in supplies. Russia had also learned lessons from 2006 - it did a much better job of managing its public relations and made a bigger show of cooperating with European governments and the EU. The situation was a grim and extended reminder of the weaknesses in the EU's energy strategy, making the compelling case for diversification. Bulgaria, for example, is almost entirely dependent on Russia for its gas supplies, with just 8% coming from domestic resources, and struggled to keep households warm and factories running. Serbia, which relies on Russia for 92% of its gas supply, also suffered badly. As a result, several central and eastern European governments are now talking about restarting old nuclear reactors. Other measures would also help, e.g., more LNG import capacity, better physical interconnections between EU states, and more storage facilities and market mechanisms to improve the flow of gas from country to country.

Title: ECS Transactions - Electrochemical Capacitor and Hybrid Power Batteries 2008 - 214th ECS Meeting
Abstract: The proceedings contain 28 papers. The topics discussed include: electrochemical capacitor performance in energy harvesting applications; hybridation of lead-acid batteries and supercaps: a mean to gain in electrical performances and in life time; tailoring electrochemical capacitor energy storage using direct write dispenser printing; activated carbon in double layer capacitors; combining nanostructured carbon electrodes and ionic liquid electrolytes to develop new electrochemical capacitors; capacitor properties of bundled single- and double-walled carbon nanotubes and their electrochemical doping mechanism; effect of doping ions on capacitance properties of polypyrrole/functionalized single-walled carbon nanotubes composites; electrochemical performance of iridium oxide thin film for supercapacitor prepared by radio frequency magnetron sputtering method; and asymmetrical electrochemical capacitors using heteropoly acid electrolytes.

Title: Battery/Energy Technology (General) - 216th ECS Meeting
Abstract: The proceedings contain 36 papers. The topics discussed include: towards the 3-d microfabrication and integration of a complete power unit used for energy autonomous wireless system; material and design options for avoiding lithium plating during charging; surface modification and fabrication of Li-ion battery components for plug-in hybrid electric vehicle; in situ neutron imaging of alkaline and lithium batteries; synthesis and characterization of polymerized ionic liquids; the state-of-energy: a new criterion for the energetic performances evaluation of electrochemical storage devices; modeling of lithium iron phosphate batteries by an equivalent electrical circuit: method of model parameterization and simulation; optimum charging profile for lithium-ion batteries to maximize energy storage and utilization; and development of multifunctional catalysts for electrooxidation of ethanol.

Title: ECS Transactions - Large Scale Energy Storage Systems - 214th ECS Meeting
Abstract: The proceedings contain 8 papers. The topics discussed include: the results of applications of energy storage systems for new energy by the demonstration projects of NEDO; grid stabilization by use of an energy storage system for a large-scale PV generation plant; development of the flooded-type ultrabattery for micro-HEV applications; zinc as an energy carrier for energy conversion and storage; triarylamine-functionalized ruthenium dyes for efficient dye-sensitized solar cells; low-current charge properties of large-scale nickel metal hydride batteries and application to photovoltaic power generation; and thermodynamic modeling of a tubular high-temperature steam electrolyzer cell.

Title: ECS Transactions - Battery and Energy Technology (General) - 214th ECS Meeting/PRiME 2008
Abstract: The proceedings contain 19 papers. The topics discussed include: renewable highest capacity boride/air energy storage; Ni - based electrodes for hydrogen and oxygen generation; the study on the electrochemical behavior of electrolysis manganese dioxide in magnesium sulfate solution by microelectrode CV and XRD; effect of ethylene oxide structures in tempo polymers on high-rate discharge properties; cathode supported honeycomb SOFCs for intermediate temperature operation; evaluation of dye-sensitized solar cells using forward bias applied impedance spectroscopy under dark; silver metal oxyfluoride perovskite for high volumetric energy storage; zinc negative electrode for direct borohydride fuel cells; hydrogen and nanostructured carbon by plasma decomposition of natural gas; improving the sulphur tolerance of nickel catalysts for running solid oxide fuel cells on waste biogas; and direct utilization of methanol on ceria-based anodes for SOFC.

Title: Large scale energy storage systems: Preface
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Hydrogen Generation from Wind Power
Abstract: Wind power has received much attention from viewpoints of the exhaustion problem of fossil fuel and global warming. Wind power generation is not possible at all times because it is strongly dependent on the weather. There are also some places where sufficient wind speed is not available. Therefore, one recent trend is generating hydrogen by using wind energy. If it is possible to transform the wind energy to hydrogen and to preserve the hydrogen in an appropriate way, then it can be kept in a stable state for a long time. In that case, the hydrogen can also be transported easily to any place. This chapter focuses on hydrogen generation from a grid connected wind farm. © 2009, Springer London.
Author Keywords: Hydrogen Storage; Wind Energy; Wind Farm; Wind Power; Wind Turbine
Index Keywords: Electric power generation; Fossil fuels; Global warming; Wind; Wind power; A-stable; Grid connected wind farms; Hydrogen generations; Recent trends; Wind speed; Hydrogen production

Title: Hydrogen
Abstract: Hydrogen energy is a clean or inexhaustible energy like renewable energy and nuclear energy. Today’s energy supply has a considerable impact on the environment. Hydrogen energy is a promising alternative solution because it is clean and environmentally safe. It also produces negligible levels of greenhouse gases and other pollutants when compared with the fossil energy sources they replace. It is well-known that hydrogen is a clean and renewable fuel. Hydrogen is a secondary source of energy — an energy carrier — which is used to move, store and deliver energy in an easily usable form. © 2009, Springer London.
Author Keywords: Hydrogen Production; Hydrogen Storage; Metal Hydride; Sewage Sludge; Visible Light Irradiation
Index Keywords: Greenhouse gases; Alternative solutions; Energy supplies; Environmentally safe; Fossil energy sources; Impact on the environment; Renewable energies; Renewable fuels; Secondary sources; Hydrogen fuels

Title: Hydrogen Policy
Abstract: Current energy policies address environmental issues including environmentally friendly technologies to increase energy supplies and encourage cleaner, more efficient energy use, air pollution, greenhouse effect (mainly reducing carbon dioxide emissions), global warming and climate change (Demirbas, 2008). In general, an energy policy includes issues of energy production, distribution and consumption. It is also the manner in which a given entity has decided to address these issues. The attributes of energy policy may include international treaties, legislation on commercial energy activities (trading, transport, storage, etc.), incentives to investment, guidelines for energy production, conversion and use (efficiency and emission standards), taxation and other public policy techniques, energy-related research and development, energy economy, general international trade agreements and marketing, energy diversity, and risk factors contrary to possible energy crisis. © 2009, Springer London.
Author Keywords: Energy Policy; European Union; Fast Pyrolysis; Fuel Cell System; International Energy Agency
Index Keywords: Air cleaners; Air quality; Carbon dioxide; Conversion efficiency; Energy policy; Environmental technology; Global warming; Greenhouse effect; Hydrogen; International trade; Laws and legislation; Taxation; Carbon dioxide emissions; Commercial energy; Energy productions; Environmental issues; Environmentally-friendly technology; Global warming and climate changes; International treaties; Research and development; Investments

Title: Wind and Wave Energy for Reverse Osmosis
Affiliations: Centre for Renewable Energy Sources (CRES), Wind Energy Department, 19th km Marathonos Ave, Pikermi, 19009, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Tzen, E., Centre for Renewable Energy Sources (CRES), Wind Energy Department, 19th km Marathonos Ave, Pikermi, 19009, Greece
Abstract: The idea of using Renewable Energy Sources (RES) to drive desalination processes is fundamentally attractive, as a considerable number of in-depth studies and real-life applications demonstrate. Renewable energy systems convert naturally occurring energy (sunlight, wind, etc.) into usable electrical, mechanical or thermal energy. Most of these systems are well established and reliable, with a significant number of applications all over the world. The selection of the most suitable technological combination for RES/desalination is an important factor in the success of a project. Wind energy turbines to drive Reverse Osmosis (RO) units is the second most used combination, following that of photovoltaic (PV)/RO systems. Only a few studies and applications have been done on the use of wave energy to drive RO units. Wave energy is a relatively new technology with only a small number of applications being used for electricity production. In this chapter, an overview of wind and wave energy technologies and their coupling with RO units for seawater desalination is presented. Additionally, a description of existing applications, economic data, as well as market potential, is provided. © 2009, Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg.
Author Keywords: Diesel Generator; Reverse Osmosis; Wave Energy; Wind Energy; Wind Turbine
Index Keywords: Desalination; Digital storage; Reverse osmosis; Wind power; Electricity production; Naturally occurring; Real-life applications; Renewable energy source; Renewable energy systems; Seawater desalination; Technological combination; Wave energy technology; Wave energy conversion

Title: Integration of an Energy Storage System into Wind Farm
Abstract: The oldest form of energy storage involves harvesting ice from lakes and rivers. The ice was stored in well insulated warehouses and sold or used throughout the year for almost everything we use mechanical refrigeration for today, including preserving food, cooling drinks, and air conditioning. The Hungarian Parliament Building in Budapest is still air conditioned with ice harvested from Lake Balaton in the winter. © 2009, Springer London.
Author Keywords: Battery Energy Storage System; Double Layer Capacitor; Energy Storage System; Voltage Source Converter; Wind Farm
Index Keywords: Air conditioning; Beverages; Energy storage; Lakes; Thermal processing (foods); Wind power; Budapest; Energy storage systems; Hungarians; Lake Balaton; Mechanical refrigeration; Wind farm; Ice

Title: ASHRAE Transactions - Papers Presented at the 2009 Winter Conference in Chicago, Illinois of the American Society of Heating, Refrigerating and Air-Conditioning Engineers, Inc.
Abstract: The proceedings contain 62 papers. The topics discussed include: hybrid ventilation control design and management; a reference environment for the calculation of the energy value of air in buildings; occupant behavior in naturally ventilated and hybrid buildings; particulate and gaseous contamination: effect on computer reliability and monitoring; air management metrics in data centers; dehumidification of outdoor air in datacom environments for air-side economizer operation; lessons learned from the cold storage fire at the Chicago world's fair of 1893; a detailed model to determine the effective solar optical properties of draperies; determining off-normal solar optical properties of insect screens; liquid cooling in data centers; heat tolerance limits for subjects exercising in heavy clothing; impact of pressurization on energy consumption for laboratories and cleanrooms; and modeling for predicting frost behavior of a fin-tube heat exchanger with thermal contact resistance.

Title: Investigation of acoustic resonance frequencies for a geometric model of thyroid gland
Source title: 15th International Symposium on Theoretical Electrical Engineering, ISTET 2009
Affiliations: Electronic and Computer Department, University of Pitesti, Romania
Authors with affiliations: Gavriloaia, G., Electronic and Computer Department, University of Pitesti, Romania
Abstract: The thyroid gland, one of the largest endocrine glands, is investigated as a resonant cavity forming a means of storing energy at a particular frequency with a small bandwidth. A number of 16 acoustic frequencies are evaluated for a geometric model of thyroid gland, by using finite element method. The spatial distribution of the extreme values of acoustic pressure is in accordance with blood supplier positions. The decrease of blood supplier efficiency and local temperature is argued when certain objects appear inside, like nodule or cysts, by showing the new spectral signatures and their special positions. © 15th International Symposium on Theoretical Electrical Engineering, ISTET 2009. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Acoustic pressure; Eigenfrequency; Eigenvalue; Resonant cavities; Thyroid cancer
Index Keywords: Energy storage; Geometry; Acoustic frequency; Acoustic pressures; Acoustic resonance; Geometric modeling; Local temperature; Special positions; Spectral signature; Supplier efficiencies; Blood

Title: Facility plans for the LHEC
Source title: DIS 2009 - Proceedings of the 17th International Workshop on Deep-Inelastic Scattering and Related Topics
Affiliations: CERNS, Geneva, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Holzer, B.J., CERNS, Geneva, Switzerland
Abstract: The LHeC aims at the generation of hadron-lepton collisions with center of mass energies in the TeV scale. The existing LHC storage ring with its 7 TeV proton beams is extended by a high energy electron accelerator in the energy range of 60 to 140 GeV. This paper presents technical considerations and parameter choices for such a machine and outlines the challenges of colliding a high intensity high energy proton and electron beam. The LHeC is presently being evaluated in the form of two options, 'ring-ring' and 'linac-ring', either of which operate simultaneously with pp or ion-ion collisions in other LHC interaction regions. Each option takes advantage of recent advances in radio-frequency, in linear acceleration, and in other associated technologies, to achieve ep luminosity as large as 1033 cm-2s -1.
Index Keywords: Elementary particles; Tellurium compounds; Center-of-mass energies; High energy proton; High-energy electron; Interaction region; Ion-ion collision; Linear accelerations; Parameter choice; Radio frequencies; Inelastic scattering

Title: The Hydrogen Economy
Abstract: The hydrogen economy is a vision for a future in which hydrogen replaces fossil fuels. There are a variety of methods for generating, storing and delivering hydrogen since no single method has yet proven superior. Economically, the wasteful hydrogen process translates to electricity from hydrogen and fuel cells costing at least four times as much as electricity from the grid. In fact, electricity would be much more efficiently used if it were sent directly to the appliances instead. Low density and extremely low boiling point of hydrogen increases the energy cost of compression or liquefaction and the investment costs of storage. The low energy content of solar irradiation dictates that photosynthetic processes operate at high conversion efficiencies and places severe restrictions on photobioreactor economics (Hallenbeck and Benemann, 2002). Looking forward, towards the end of the century, solar-hydrogen type of fuels could be an option for a global energy economy. © 2009, Springer London.
Author Keywords: Energy Carrier; Fast Pyrolysis; Fuel Cell; National Renewable Energy Laboratory; Sulfur Removal
Index Keywords: Conversion efficiency; Costs; Economics; Fossil fuels; Fuel cells; Hydrogen fuels; Hydrogen storage; Investments; Energy content; Global energy; High conversion efficiency; Investment costs; Low density; Photobiore-actor; Solar hydrogen; Solar irradiation; Hydrogen economy

Title: Studying the potential efficiency of low heat rejection HCCI engines with a Stochastic Reactor Model
Affiliations: Lund University, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Tunér, M., Lund University, Sweden
Abstract: The main losses in internal combustion engines are the heat losses to the cylinder walls and to the exhaust gases. Adiabatic, or low heat rejection engines, have received interest and been studied in several periods in history. Typically, however, these attempts have had to be abandoned when problems with lubrication and overheating components could not be solved satisfactorily. The latest years have seen the emerging of low temperature combustion in engines as well as computational powers that provide new options for highly efficient engines with low heat rejection. Stochastic Reactor Models (SRM) are highly efficient in modeling the kinetics decided low temperature combustion in HCCI and PPC engines. Containing the means to define the variations within the cylinder while employing detailed chemistry, micro mixing and heat transfer modeling, the interaction between heat transfer, exhaust gas energy and the combustion process can be studied with the SRM. A multidimensional study was setup with the SRM to investigate the interaction between heat transfer, exhaust gas energy and the combustion process and its dependency from level of cylinder wall thermal insulation or heat storage, inlet pressure, inlet temperature, mixture strength, mixture and temperature stratification, compression ratio, valve timing, residual gas amount and fuel effects. The investigation reaches into combustion and engine operating regimes that so far have not been investigated experimentally before. It is found that by using this combined approach a multidimensional span of engine and combustion characteristics can be produced, giving deeper insights in the potential for efficiency increase through combined low temperature combustion and low heat rejection. Copyright © 2009 SAE International.
Index Keywords: Adiabatic engines; Combustion; Compression ratio (machinery); Diesel engines; Exhaust gases; Gas fuel storage; Heat sinks; Heat storage; Heat transfer; Mixers (machinery); Mixtures; Stochastic systems; Temperature; Thermal insulation; Combustion characteristics; Efficiency increase; Heat transfer model; Low heat rejection engine; Low temperature combustion; Potential efficiency; Stochastic reactor models; Temperature stratification; Stochastic models

Authors: Kural E., Ararat O., Sezer V., Solak Y., Kutuk O., Ozsu E., Ucarol H.
Title: Development of a hybrid electric mid-sized bus for urban transport
Affiliations: TUBITAK Marmara Research Center, Energy Institute
Authors with affiliations: Kural, E., TUBITAK Marmara Research Center, Energy Institute; Ararat, O., TUBITAK Marmara Research Center, Energy Institute; Sezer, V., TUBITAK Marmara Research Center, Energy Institute; Solak, Y., TUBITAK Marmara Research Center, Energy Institute; Kutuk, O., TUBITAK Marmara Research Center, Energy Institute; Ozsu, E., TUBITAK Marmara Research Center, Energy Institute; Ucarol, H., TUBITAK Marmara Research Center, Energy Institute
Abstract: Hybrid vehicles acquired substantial importance with the advantages that are offered in terms of fuel consumption and emitted pollutants. There are several hybrid vehicle concepts developed for passenger cars mostly specialized with fuel efficient strategies in the market and more control schemes are still in the development process. Mid sized hybrid-buses, as a commonly used transport vehicle in urban traffic, can also be optimized with enhanced emission characteristics as well as with better fuel consumption performance. The objective of this paper is to summarize the evaluation of the project related to the development of a hybrid bus vehicle concept operating for urban transport: The development of control strategies, sizing of new traction and energy storage components, developing new concepts and strategies to handle the secondary power consuming devices on the mid-bus like air brakes or hydraulic steering system, emission measurement tests are the main steps of the development procedure. Copyright © 2009 SAE International.
Index Keywords: Air brakes; Automobile steering equipment; Bus transportation; Buses; Fuels; Hybrid vehicles; Planning; Powertrains; Traction control; Control strategies; Development process; Efficient strategy; Emission measurement; Energy storage components; Enhanced Emission; Steering systems; Transport vehicles; Urban transportation

Authors: Thornton M.J., Alleman T.L., Luecke J., McCormick R.L.
Title: Impacts of biodiesel fuel blends oil dilution on light-duty diesel engine operation
Affiliations: National Renewable Energy Laboratory
Authors with affiliations: Thornton, M.J., National Renewable Energy Laboratory; Alleman, T.L., National Renewable Energy Laboratory; Luecke, J., National Renewable Energy Laboratory; McCormick, R.L., National Renewable Energy Laboratory
Abstract: Increasing interest in biofuelsspecifically, biodiesel as a pathway to energy diversity and securityhave necessitated the need for research on the performance and utilization of these fuels and fuel blends in current and future vehicle fleets. One critical research area is related to achieving a full understanding of the impact of biodiesel fuel blends on advanced emission control systems. In addition, the use of biodiesel fuel blends can degrade diesel engine oil performance and impact the oil drain interval requirements. There is limited information related to the impact of biodiesel fuel blends on oil dilution. This paper assesses the oil dilution impacts on an engine operating in conjunction with a diesel particle filter (DPF), oxides of nitrogen (NOx) storage, a selective catalytic reduction (SCR) emission control system, and a 20% biodiesel (soy-derived) fuel blend. The main focus was on the biodiesel oil dilution levels observed during an accelerated aging protocol and an assessment of the potential impacts on the engine and emissions control systems. For the NOx storage system (which requires a late in-cylinder fuel injection for regeneration), biodiesel oil dilution levels ranged from 5%-10%. For the SCR system (which used a urea solution as a reductant and late in-cylinder fuel injection for diesel particle filter regeneration), biodiesel oil dilution ranged from <4%-8%. These observations were made over typical oil drain intervals. Despite these observed biodiesel oil dilution levels, there were no observed impacts on performance of the engine or the emission control systems. Copyright © 2009 SAE International.
Index Keywords: Biodiesel; Control systems; Diesel engines; Dilution; Emission control; Fuel injection; Monte Carlo methods; Nitrogen oxides; Powertrains; Selective catalytic reduction; Urea; Accelerated aging; Critical researches; Diesel engine oil; Emissions control systems; Light-duty diesel engines; Limited information; Oxides of nitrogen; Potential impacts; Fuel storage

Authors: Neuman M., Sandberg H., Wahlberg B., Folkesson A.
Title: Modelling and control of series HEVs including resistive losses and varying engine efficiency
Affiliations: Scania CV AB and Automatic Control, Royal Institute of Technology, Sweden; Automatic Control, Royal Institute of Technology, Sweden; Scania CV AB, SE-151 87, Södertälje, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Neuman, M., Scania CV AB and Automatic Control, Royal Institute of Technology, Sweden, Scania CV AB, SE-151 87, Södertälje, Sweden; Sandberg, H., Automatic Control, Royal Institute of Technology, Sweden; Wahlberg, B., Automatic Control, Royal Institute of Technology, Sweden; Folkesson, A., Scania CV AB, SE-151 87, Södertälje, Sweden
Abstract: A model of a series HEV (Hybrid Electric Vehicle) including resistive losses in the energy storage and varying engine and generator efficiency is presented. The purpose is to study how system properties affect the optimal control of series HEVs. We show that there is an inherent trade-off in the control of such a system, based on the characteristics of the efficiency curve of the EGU (Engine and Generator Unit) together with the energy storage internal resistance, capacitance and energy level. The relation between these properties determines the optimal control of the EGU, and this is thus the mechanism behind all optimal control problems using a similar model setup. We illustrate our reasoning using deterministic dynamic programming where system properties are varied and the optimal control is studied. Copyright © 2009 SAE International.
Index Keywords: Dynamic programming; Economic and social effects; Electric losses; Energy efficiency; Energy storage; Engines; Optimal control systems; Efficiency curves; Engine efficiency; Generator efficiency; Internal resistance; Modelling and controls; Optimal control problem; Optimal controls; System property; Hybrid vehicles

Title: Fuel Cells - Exploratory Fuel Cells | Regenerative Fuel Cells
Affiliations: University of Split, Split, Croatia
Authors with affiliations: Barbir, F., University of Split, Split, Croatia
Abstract: Regenerative fuel cell (RFC) can operate both as a fuel cell, thus generating power, and as an electrolyzer, thus generating its own fuel. As such, it is an energy storage device. Hydrogen/oxygen RFCs may have high energy density (>400 Wh kg -1). Unlike battery systems, the RFC separates the power and energy components of the system. The power output of the system is determined by the size of the fuel cell stack and the energy capacity of the system corresponds to the size of the hydrogen (and oxygen) storage subsystem, which are usually high-pressure gas tanks. It may be used in applications where relatively large amounts of electricity need to be stored, such as energy storage for remote off-grid power sources, emergency or backup power generation, zero-emission vehicles, hybrid energy storage/propulsion systems for underwater vehicles, spacecraft, and high-altitude long-endurance solar rechargeable aircraft. © 2009 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Backup power; Electrolyzer; Energy density; Hydrogen; Static feed; Unitized stack

Title: Internal Energy Storage
Affiliations: Lund University, Lund, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Brodin, A., Lund University, Lund, Sweden
Abstract: To ensure an even supply of fuel for the cells, animals must store energy in various ways, for example, as glycogen or fat. The carbohydrate glycogen is oxygen efficient and primarily stored for high-intensity work. Fat is lighter and more energy rich and thus suitable for long-term storage. Adaptive fat regulation has received special attention in birds since it is important for flying organisms to minimize body mass. Three systems have been thoroughly studied: (1) fat regulation in small birds in cold winter environments, (2) fuel regulation in migrating birds, and (3) fat regulation in hummingbirds. I discuss these systems as well as some other examples of energy storing in animals. © 2010 Elsevier Ltd All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Allometric effects; Carbohydrates; Energy management; Energy regulation; Energy reserves; Energy storing; Fat; Fuel; Hypothermia; Little bird in winter; Torpor

Title: Food Properties: An overview
Affiliations: Department of Food Science and Nutrition, Sultan Qaboos University, Muscat, Oman
Authors with affiliations: Shafiur Rahman, M., Department of Food Science and Nutrition, Sultan Qaboos University, Muscat, Oman
Abstract: A property of a system or material is any observable attribute or characteristic of that system or material. The state of a system or material can be defined by listing its properties (ASHRAE, 1993). A food property is a particular measure of the food’s behavior as a matter, its behavior with respect to energy, its interaction with the human senses, or its efficacy in promoting human health and well-being (McCarthy, 1997; Rahman and McCarthy, 1999). It is always attempted to preserve product characteristics at a desirable level for as long as possible. Food properties, in turn, define the functionality of foods (Karel, 1999). Food functionality, as defined by Karel, refers to the control of food properties that provides a desired set of organoleptic properties, wholesomeness (including health-related functions), as well as properties related to processing and engineering, in particular, ease of processing, storage stability, and minimum environmental impact. © 2009 by Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.
Index Keywords: Environmental impact; Food storage; Food properties; Human health; Human sense; Organoleptic properties; Product characteristics; Related functions; Storage stability; Well being; Functional food

Title: Goliat field development circular FPSO in harsh environment
Source title: Offshore Mediterranean Conference and Exhibition 2009, OMC 2009
Affiliations: Eni Norge AS, Norway
Authors with affiliations: Tangvald, T.B., Eni Norge AS, Norway; Kiste, K., Eni Norge AS, Norway
Abstract: The Goliat field is located on the Norwegian part of the Barents Sea. Goliat will be the first oil field to be developed in an area that is considered very important with respect to fishing and wild life resources. The Goliat field will be developed by a Floating Production, Storage and Offloading vessel of novel circular design connected to eight subsea templates containing production, water injection and gas injection wells. The produced oil will be exported via dedicated shuttle tankers to the commercial market and it is expected that the limited gas resources over time can be export via available infrastructure in the area. The development solution is based on use of a circular and geo-stationary FPSO that will receive electric power from the onshore grid as one mean to reduce emission of green house gases. © 2009 Offshore Mediterranean Conference. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Energy resources; Greenhouse gases; Offshore oil well production; Oil tankers; Petroleum deposits; Water injection; Circular designs; Commercial market; Development solutions; Field development; Floating production , storage and offloading; Gas-injection wells; Harsh environment; Shuttle tankers; Injection (oil wells)

Title: Strategic petroleum reserve
Authors with affiliations: Bamberger, R.
Abstract: Hurricane Katrina made landfall early in the morning of August 29, inflicting severe damage and shutting down oil and gas production and refining activities in the Gulf of Mexico. Damage assessments continue. On August 31, Secretary of Energy Bodman indicated that the Bush Administration was authorizing releases of Strategic Petroleum Reserve (SPR) crude oil. Operating refineries whose crude supply has been interrupted by the hurricane can request a loan or swap of crude from the SPR. By September 2, three requests for loans totaling 8.5 million barrels had been approved; a few others are pending. The Administration also announced it was making 30 million barrels available. However, as a policy tool to respond to the crisis, the SPR has limitations, because a barrel of crude contributes to product supply only if there is refining capacity to turn the crude into gasoline or diesel fuel. Consequently, recovery from the hurricane’s effects will depend on resumption of production and refining operations in the Gulf, and ability to transport petroleum products. On August 8, 2005, the President signed the Energy Policy Act of 2005 (H.R. 6). The bill as enacted permanently authorizes the SPR and requires, “as expeditiously as practicable,” expansion of the SPR to its authorized maximum of 1 billion barrels. The SPR, with a capacity of 727 million barrels, currently holds 700 million barrels, though the amount will decline some as refiners borrow crude. Congress authorized the SPR in the Energy Policy and Conservation Act (EPCA, P.L. 94-163) to help prevent a repetition of the economic dislocation caused by the 1973-74 Arab oil embargo. The program is managed by the Department of Energy (DOE). Physically, the SPR comprises five underground storage facilities, hollowed out from naturally occurring salt domes in Texas and Louisiana. Four of the storage sites are operable at this time. A Northeast Heating Oil Reserve (NHOR) holds 2 million barrels of heating oil in aboveground storage. A formula governs its use, and it has yet to be tapped. In mid-November 2001, President Bush ordered fill of the SPR to its capacity (at that time) of 700 million barrels, principally with oil acquired as royalty-in-kind (RIK) for production from federal offshore leases. Deliveries of RIK oil ended in August 2005 when the SPR reached 700 million barrels. The bill signed by the President also requires the Secretary of Energy to fill the SPR to its authorized size of one billion barrels. Within one year of enactment, the Secretary will select sites — from among those that have been previously studied — for the expansion. The Secretary is also required to develop procedures for achieving the fill objective without “incurring excessive cost,” or using fill options that would place upward pressure on prices. Any fill policy is also to take into consideration minimizing income foregone to the Treasury by filling the SPR with additional RIK oil. Given these parameters and the difficulty of predicting the state of oil markets in the future, it is unclear whether, once sites are identified, fill will be resumed The Administration request for FY2006 for the SPR itself was $166.0 million, a reduction of roughly $4 million from the FY2005 appropriation. No new money was requested for the NHOR in FY2006 owing to prior year balances of $5.3 million. The Houseand Senate-passed versions of the FY2006 Energy and Water Development Appropriations bill support the levels proposed by the Administration. © 2009 by Nova Science Publishers, Inc. Title: Living and Mobility - blue angel 3 with SAM for a demonstration platform of V2G
Affiliations: Center of Competence IIEE, Lucerne University of Applied Sciences and Arts, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Haerri, V.V., Center of Competence IIEE, Lucerne University of Applied Sciences and Arts, Switzerland; Schweizer, P., Center of Competence IIEE, Lucerne University of Applied Sciences and Arts, Switzerland
Abstract: The development of the Blue-Angel light HEV started already in its 1st generation in 1992. In 2006, the 3rd generation redesign, first as a HEV and later on as a full EV with range extender, was started. The current design-concept is presented in this paper. Emphasis is put on the energy storage integration with a so called SAM2 storage 3rd generation which stands in communication with the energy management of the appropriate building. This paper presents the integration of Blue-Angel in the strategic field of research "living and mobility" of CC IIEE1 of the Lucerne University of Applied Sciences and Arts as well as the V2G concept. In this concept, PHEVs and EVs can be utilized for harnessing renewable energy and for providing power for both residential and commercial customers. The amount and the direction of power flow amongst the sub-systems, which include the grid, renewable energy sources, household load and Blue- Angel is part of a new management system. The proposed system is an open and universal platform and is expected to gain popularity amongst both commercial and residential users interested in resolving the global energy crisis. The system components will be demonstrated in a show-area platform of the Lucerne University of Applied Sciences and Arts in Horw-Lucerne as well as in a local utility. © 2009 AVERE.

Authors: Barrero R., Coosemans T., van Mierlo J.
Title: Hybrid buses: Defining the power flow management strategy and energy storage system needs
Affiliations: Vrije UniversiteitBrussel, IR-ETEC, Pleinlaan 2, Elsene, B-1050, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Barrero, R., Vrije UniversiteitBrussel, IR-ETEC, Pleinlaan 2, Elsene, B-1050, Belgium; Coosemans, T., Vrije UniversiteitBrussel, IR-ETEC, Pleinlaan 2, Elsene, B-1050, Belgium; van Mierlo, J., Vrije UniversiteitBrussel, IR-ETEC, Pleinlaan 2, Elsene, B-1050, Belgium
Abstract: The following article will analyze the benefits of retrofitting a diesel-electric bus by hybridizing its drive train with a supercapacitor based energy storage system (ESS). Several power flow management strategies will be proposed and compared; and their respective ESSs will be sized and designed accordingly. The energy savings achieved range between 32 % and 40%, due to braking energy recovery and an improved ICE efficiency, and show the importance of the power flow strategy. Results are obtained by means of a quasi-static 'backwards/forward looking' simulation program, developed for this purpose, which includes a dynamic model of the ICE. Performance of the conventional bus and the hybrid bus is also compared. © 2009 AVERE.
Author Keywords: Efficiency; Energy storage; HEV; Public transport; Simulation; Supercapacitor

Authors: Verbrugge B., Heremans Y., Van Mulders F., Culcu H., van den Bossche P., van Mierlo J.
Title: Modelling the RESS: Describing Electrical Parameters of Batteries and electric Double-Layer capacitors through measurements
Affiliations: Building Z, Pleinlaan 2, Brussel, 1050, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Verbrugge, B., Building Z, Pleinlaan 2, Brussel, 1050, Belgium; Heremans, Y., Building Z, Pleinlaan 2, Brussel, 1050, Belgium; Van Mulders, F., Building Z, Pleinlaan 2, Brussel, 1050, Belgium; Culcu, H., Building Z, Pleinlaan 2, Brussel, 1050, Belgium; van den Bossche, P., Building Z, Pleinlaan 2, Brussel, 1050, Belgium; van Mierlo, J., Building Z, Pleinlaan 2, Brussel, 1050, Belgium
Abstract: Being able to predict the behaviour of Rechargeable Energy Storage Systems (RESS) such as batteries and Electric Double-Layer Capacitors (EDLC) relies on the models used to represent them. Research on the development and enhancement of these models is performed on two tracks: on one hand by defining the model topology, where a trade-off is sought between the reduction of components in the model equivalent scheme and the ability of the model to describe all potential system behaviour and, on the other hand by improving the method of calculating the magnitudes of the different components in the model. The storage devices examined in this paper are divided in two groups, electrochemical devices and electrical double layer capacitors. The first group consists of lead-acid, lithium, Ni-Cd and Ni-MH batteries. The second group comprises of Electric Double-Layer Capacitors (EDLC). For every model used to describe a battery or EDLC, different techniques are implemented to calculate the magnitude of the components. The work presented in this paper will elaborate to the calculating method used in NREL's FreedomCAR test-manual adapted to fit different battery- and EDLC models. This method consists of an iterative approach to the equations of the model using data gathered from performing tests on the battery or supercapacitor. Validation of the models obtained through this calculating method will be done by performance tests on the storage devices. As the models of batteries and supercapacitors are a key aspect in the simulation software for hybrid-vehicles more accurate models result in more accurate simulations. These simulation programs depend upon the underlying component models, the data generated by which determines the accuracy of the program's data-output. The availability of reliable storage RESS models will thus be a key element in to allow overall vehicle modelling. © 2009 AVERE.
Author Keywords: Battery model; EDLC; Simulation

Authors: Trovão J.P., Pereirinha P.G., Jorge H.M.
Title: Design methodology of energy storage systems for a small electric vehicle
Affiliations: IPC-ISEC, Polytechnic Institute of Coimbra, Rua Pedro Nunes, Coimbra, Portugal; DEEC - FCTUC, University of Coimbra - Pólo II, Coimbra, P-3030-290, Portugal; INESC-Coimbra, Institute for Systems and Computers Engineering at Coimbra, Portugal; APVE, Portuguese Electric Vehicle Association Portuguese Branch of AVERE, Lisboa, Portugal
Authors with affiliations: Trovão, J.P., IPC-ISEC, Polytechnic Institute of Coimbra, Rua Pedro Nunes, Coimbra, Portugal, INESC-Coimbra, Institute for Systems and Computers Engineering at Coimbra, Portugal; Pereirinha, P.G., IPC-ISEC, Polytechnic Institute of Coimbra, Rua Pedro Nunes, Coimbra, Portugal, INESC-Coimbra, Institute for Systems and Computers Engineering at Coimbra, Portugal, APVE, Portuguese Electric Vehicle Association Portuguese Branch of AVERE, Lisboa, Portugal; Jorge, H.M., DEEC - FCTUC, University of Coimbra - Pólo II, Coimbra, P-3030-290, Portugal, INESC-Coimbra, Institute for Systems and Computers Engineering at Coimbra, Portugal
Abstract: With the current state of technological development, the future of Electric Vehicles (EVs) seems to go through the hybridization of various Energy Storage Systems (ESSs). This strategy seeks to benefit from the best qualities of each available energy source, and is especially useful in urban driving. In this work, the need for multiple energy sources hybridization is addressed. A methodology to optimize the sizing of the ESSs for an electric vehicle taking as example the ISEC-VEIL project, using different driving cycles, maximum speed, a specified acceleration, energy regeneration and gradeability requests are presented. It is also studied the possibility of using a backup system based on solar energy, that may be considered in the design, or as an extra to cope with unforeseen routines and to minimize the recharge of ESSs. Some simulation results of multiple energy sources hybridization are presented, considering different ESSs and different scenarios for the small presented EV, in order to verify the proposed designs. © 2009 AVERE.

Authors: Ciosek K., Killiches S., Zavalis T., Behm M., Johansson P., Edström K., Jacobsson P., Lindbergh G.
Title: Energy storage activities in the Swedish hybrid vehicle centre
Affiliations: Department of Applied Physics, Condensed Matter Physics, Chalmers University of Technology, Goteborg, SE-412 96, Sweden; Department of Materials Chemistry, Angstrom Laboratory, Uppsala University, Uppsala, SE-751 21, Sweden; School of Chemical Science and Engineering, Department of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Applied Electrochemistry, KTH Royal institute of Technology, Stockholm, SE-100 44, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Ciosek, K., Department of Materials Chemistry, Angstrom Laboratory, Uppsala University, Uppsala, SE-751 21, Sweden; Killiches, S., Department of Applied Physics, Condensed Matter Physics, Chalmers University of Technology, Goteborg, SE-412 96, Sweden; Zavalis, T., School of Chemical Science and Engineering, Department of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Applied Electrochemistry, KTH Royal institute of Technology, Stockholm, SE-100 44, Sweden; Behm, M., School of Chemical Science and Engineering, Department of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Applied Electrochemistry, KTH Royal institute of Technology, Stockholm, SE-100 44, Sweden; Johansson, P., Department of Applied Physics, Condensed Matter Physics, Chalmers University of Technology, Goteborg, SE-412 96, Sweden; Edström, K., Department of Materials Chemistry, Angstrom Laboratory, Uppsala University, Uppsala, SE-751 21, Sweden; Jacobsson, P., Department of Applied Physics, Condensed Matter Physics, Chalmers University of Technology, Goteborg, SE-412 96, Sweden; Lindbergh, G., School of Chemical Science and Engineering, Department of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Applied Electrochemistry, KTH Royal institute of Technology, Stockholm, SE-100 44, Sweden
Abstract: Significant efforts are put worldwide on developing new concepts for vehicle propulsion with the hybrid electric vehicle (HEV) being a prominent example. Hybrid technology is clearly a strategic future activity for automotive industries and in response to the rapid development in the area; the Swedish Hybrid Vehicle Centre (SHC) was formed in 2007 to join forces between Swedish industry and academia in the field. The centre emphasizes a holistic view to meet the environmental and societal needs with new technological solutions. The research within SHC is currently divided into three different themes whereof we here describe the Energy Storage theme with emphasis on the activities carried out at the involved universities in the current main project areas: Cell Properties, Electrode Materials and Electrolyte Additives. Examples are given on how these projects attacks the problems at hand separately, but also how we create synergy effects between the projects. As an example cell modelling is performed given a specific chemistry and cycling scheme, the same parameters are used for electrochemical experiments which provide macroscopic data that are connected with molecular level actions in the electrodes, the electrolyte, and the interfaces. All this is done using our base-line chemistry and a subsequent route is to investigate the role of different additives to overcome the limitations that are observed. © 2009 AVERE.

Authors: Conte F.V., Gollob P., Lacher H.
Title: Safety in the battery design: The short circuit
Affiliations: Arsenal Research Österreichisches Forschungs-und Prüfzentrum Arsenal GmbH, Giefinggasse 2, Vienna, A-1210, Austria
Authors with affiliations: Conte, F.V., Arsenal Research Österreichisches Forschungs-und Prüfzentrum Arsenal GmbH, Giefinggasse 2, Vienna, A-1210, Austria; Gollob, P., Arsenal Research Österreichisches Forschungs-und Prüfzentrum Arsenal GmbH, Giefinggasse 2, Vienna, A-1210, Austria; Lacher, H., Arsenal Research Österreichisches Forschungs-und Prüfzentrum Arsenal GmbH, Giefinggasse 2, Vienna, A-1210, Austria
Abstract: The energy storage system is one of the key components of any electric vehicle powertrain. When lithium based energy storages are used it is important to investigate carefully the safety aspects, because the safety and cost were the main aspects which prevented the introduction of lithium ion in automotive application. This work describes the methods adopted in arsenal research for developing energy storage system for advanced electric power-train. The focus will be on lithium ion battery technology. The correct cell selection and its performance assessment could ensure the achievement of a performing and inexpensive energy storage system. But for ensuring the harmless of the energy storage system a safety concept and a consequent design should be also present. The present work shows the different requirements to take into account for the energy storage system design during the development of HEV and EV vehicles within arsenal research laboratories. Particular attention is given to the abuse conditions and their corresponding test methods during the development phase. The paper presents the safety concerns regarding the short circuit, its measurements method and the failure pathways. Results of short circuit abuse tests are analysed and indication regarding the design is given. © 2009 AVERE.

Title: São Miguel Island as a case study on a possible usage of electric vehicle to store energy
Affiliations: MIT Portugal Program, Portugal
Authors with affiliations: Kadurek, P., MIT Portugal Program, Portugal
Abstract: Energy systems operation in isolated areas is frequently based on imported fossil fuels, which is a problem in different dimensions including environmental, economic and security of supply, with the latter being particularly relevant for any isolated system like Islands. Renewable energy is regarded as a solution to this problem, mainly in its transformation to electricity. This, however, excludes the impact of the transportation sector that represents a significant component of the imported fuels consumption. Other main limitation associated to renewable electricity consists on the need to increase the storage capacity that might attenuate the effect of intermittence of renewable energy sources and the disparity between supply and demand. In both problems - that are associated with renewable energy management - Plug-in Electric Vehicles (PEV) could be a part of the solution in that the use of vehicle to grid (V2G) technology can provide storage of electric energy during low demand times and use it to match the demand in peak hours and/or to avoid fossil fuel consumption. Therefore, some of the main questions are: could the large scale PEV penetration lead to increases in the fraction of electricity produced from renewable? Is the usage of PEV batteries as a storage system truly the best solution? São Miguel Island is the main electricity consumer in the whole Azores's archipelago. There is no power connection to any major grid or even with other Islands. This work analyses a case study of isolated electricity grid, where energy systems modelling is used to assess to different roll out scenarios for large scale PEV penetration and discuss the possibility to increase the potential for the use of renewable electricity. © 2009 AVERE.

Authors: Clement-Nyns K., Haesen E., Driesen J.
Title: Analysis of the impact of plug-in hybrid electric vehicles on residential distribution grids by using quadratic and dynamic programming
Affiliations: Katholieke Universiteit Leuven, Kasteelpark Arenberg 10 Box 2445, Leuven, 3001, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Clement-Nyns, K., Katholieke Universiteit Leuven, Kasteelpark Arenberg 10 Box 2445, Leuven, 3001, Belgium; Haesen, E., Katholieke Universiteit Leuven, Kasteelpark Arenberg 10 Box 2445, Leuven, 3001, Belgium; Driesen, J., Katholieke Universiteit Leuven, Kasteelpark Arenberg 10 Box 2445, Leuven, 3001, Belgium
Abstract: The charging of batteries of plug-in hybrid electric vehicles at home at standard outlets has an impact on the distribution grid which may require serious investments in grid expansion. The coordination of the charging gives an improvement of the grid exploitation in terms of reduced power losses and voltage deviations with respect to uncoordinated charging. The vehicles must be dispatchable to achieve the most efficient solution. As the exact forecasting of household loads is not possible, stochastic programming is introduced. Two main techniques are analyzed in this paper: quadratic and dynamic programming. Both techniques are compared in results and storage requirements. The charging can be coordinated directly or indirectly by the grid utility or an aggregator who will sell the aggregated demand of PHEVs at the utility. PHEVs can also discharge and so inject energy in the grid to restrict voltage drops. The amount of energy that is injected in the grid depends on the price tariffs, the charging and discharging efficiencies and the battery energy content. The impact of a voltage controller embedded in a PHEV charger is regarded in this paper. A day and night tariff are applied. The charging and discharging of vehicles can respond to real-time pricing or on a price-schedule as well. Voltage control is the first step in the utilization of distributed resources like PHEVs for ancillary services. © 2009 AVERE.
Author Keywords: Charging; Energy; Optimization; Plug-in hybrid electric vehicles

Authors: Sergeant N., Boureima F.-S., Matheys J., Timmermans J.-M., Van Mierlo J.
Title: An environmental analysis of FCEV and H2-ICE vehicles using the Ecoscore methodology
Affiliations: Vrije Universiteit Brussel, Department ETEC, Building Z, Pleinlaan 2, Brussels, 1050, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Sergeant, N., Vrije Universiteit Brussel, Department ETEC, Building Z, Pleinlaan 2, Brussels, 1050, Belgium; Boureima, F.-S., Vrije Universiteit Brussel, Department ETEC, Building Z, Pleinlaan 2, Brussels, 1050, Belgium; Matheys, J., Vrije Universiteit Brussel, Department ETEC, Building Z, Pleinlaan 2, Brussels, 1050, Belgium; Timmermans, J.-M., Vrije Universiteit Brussel, Department ETEC, Building Z, Pleinlaan 2, Brussels, 1050, Belgium; Van Mierlo, J., Vrije Universiteit Brussel, Department ETEC, Building Z, Pleinlaan 2, Brussels, 1050, Belgium
Abstract: The environmental issues caused by fossil fuels for transportation are numerous: greenhouse gas emissions are enhancing global warming, city smog, ozone and noise are causing major health problems, acid rain impacts our ecosystems, etc. Strong research efforts have therefore been performed towards alternative fuels and drive trains and hydrogen is still one of the most promising - but at the same time controversial - possibilities. The environmental impact of hydrogen - used in a fuel cell (FCEV) or internal combustion engine vehicle (ICEV) - depends strongly on the production pathway for hydrogen and should therefore be evaluated on a well-to-wheel basis. In this paper, the Ecoscore methodology is used to assess the environmental impact of H2-ICE and fuel cell vehicles on a well-to-wheel basis. The Ecoscore is an environmental indicator for vehicles taking into account the impact on global warming, air quality depletion (divided into impact on human health and ecosystems) and noise. The Ecoscores of two FCEV and one H2-ICEV are calculated for different hydrogen production pathways (electrolysis and Steam Methane Reforming (SMR)), as well as for different methods of hydrogen storage (compression and liquefaction) and distribution (pipeline and truck). The highest Ecoscores - and thus best results - are obtained for vehicles using hydrogen from electrolysis produced with 100 % renewable energy, followed by SMR and then electrolysis using the Belgian electricity mix. Compression appears to be better than liquefaction to store hydrogen due to the high energy use for the liquefaction process, and this compressed hydrogen should be transported through pipelines in stead of by trucks to obtain the best environmental performance. © 2009 AVERE.
Author Keywords: Energy; Environment; Fuel cell; Hydrogen; ICE (internal combustion engine)
